149398375.review:
While there's some pixellated gore and jumpscares, this is more of a psychological (*) horror walking sim. As far as I know, you can't fail or die, and there's only one ending. Since the game is almost always on sale for under $1, I don't have a problem recommending it for a casual player that doesn't mind being startled on occasion. It held my attention and I'll play the sequel.

(*) I have to use "psychological" loosely though, as the game's theme is overt and even explicitly stated a few times in the script. Unlike, say, Soma or especially Lone Survivor (despite similar visuals of the latter), there's little here in terms of potential for introspection, philosophy, interpretation, theory-crafting etc. I will admit to one eureka moment in the 13th hour, when an early character's brief screentime suddenly made sense, for what that's worth.

[h1]The Good[/h1]
+Environments suitably unsettling
+Can play original or deluxe version
+Can rebind controls
+Some minor humor if you try off-the-wall stuff

[h1]YMMV[/h1]
~Themes aren't very subtle or thought-provoking
~Only ~2 hours long (as store page says, but people dont read)
~Contains a far amount of walking back and forth
~Puzzles require some intuitive trial and error
~Frequent minor jumpscares, but rarely cheap
~Moderate swearing
~Moderate gore and references to suicide
~Some objects can only be inspected from specific sides or small areas
~Options don't take into account if you're using controller

[h1]The Bad[/h1]
-Can't disable distracting controller vibration
-Too much backtracking required in mushroom puzzle

Played on:
i7-12700, RTX3060, 16GB DDR4-3200 @ 1920x1080
Using PowerA Enhanced Wired Controller for Xbox Series X|S

A good, short pixel art psychological horror game. The gameplay is a side-scrolling story with puzzles throughout. 143429902.review:
Had this game sitting in the library for so long and decided to give it a go for the achievements. I had zero expectations walking in but came out feeling all sorts of heavy emotions at the end. [b]For anyone going through a rough time, please do not play this game until you're in a better state of mind.[/b] The game does take its toil on your heart as you progress deeper into the story.

Distraint is a psychological horror that tells the story of our protagonist, Price (a little ironic for the choice of name used here), who is your average nobody trying to seek a better life for himself. We start off with the task of seizing the property of an elderly woman. Although he feels conflicted, he tries to convince himself that it's just a job. [spoiler]As we progress down the road seizing property after property, Price slowly climbs up the corporate ladder and is leading a better life than before but at the [i]price[/i] of his morality. At the end of the journey, he couldn't live with himself for the moral wrongdoings that he has done to others and the general lack of morals and ethics in the corporate world. His story ends but another one begins and we find out that he's just another insignificant cog in the machine as another easily takes his place thereafter. [/spoiler]

The gameplay is relatively straightforward with simple controls but it does get confusing at [b]one[/b] particular stage. It's creepy and everything from the artwork to the music only adds to the overall dark and depressing atmosphere. Although the entire game feels like one crazy fever dream, it does hit close to home as it reflects similarities of the ugliness in the real world.

143413359.review: This game saved me from depression 10/10

143293535.review:
i review games on steam after i 100% complete them! check out my reviews to see all the games i have completed!

distraint is a 2D horror adventure game developed and published by jesse makkonen, who had previously released silence of the sleep in 2014. despite not liking horror games generally, let alone a indie horror game, i've genuinely enjoyed jesse makkonen's take on the genre and his style of games is unique and even distraint was particularly different from silence of the sleep. both had their own cool aesthetic and while both are great, distraint has better color and overall graphic/art design. you can definitely tell he got a lot better at almost all aspects of game development while making this, especially when comparing it to his first game. the sound design is something i also specifically want to single out, as i found it to be expertly crafted as it does a lot of the heavy lifting regarding the "psychological horror" aspect of the game. 

the story itself is also pretty great, showing how greed or money can lead people down dark paths. while the simple controls can turn some players off, i liked how the dev managed to make such a simple game mechanically go a long way just off of the things like sound design, storytelling, and atmospheric horror. i really enjoyed this, and i am very excited to get to the sequel in the future. this is extremely advanced and sophisticated for what seems like a simple side-scrolling game. $5 full price can seem a little steep, especially because of the shorter length of the game (i beat it in just over two hours and got all the achievements in less than three hours total). for this reason, i recommend waiting for a sale and/or grabbing this in a bundle with other games. worst case, you can routinely find this for less than a dollar on sale fairly often.

139979454.review:
Distraint is a simple, well-written game and worthy of your time.  I wouldn't characterize it as a "horror" game.  More along the lines of tragedy.

Best aspects of development: it's sophisticated, cerebral, and generally advanced for its nature.  Don't be fooled by the 2D pixelated graphics.  Only WASD for movement, E for action, and a 3 slot inventory.  

Though there are gaps in logic, there's nothing to complain about,  My only recommendation is a design revision of a single puzzle that is time sensitive -- you'll probably have to read guides on the maze with chemicals.  Game is 8-9 hour endeavor.  Overall, there's little to no replay-ability other than for achievement hunting.  

Thumbs up!  :)

139409028.review:
[i]Greed, Lust, Envy, Pride, Wrath, Gluttony, and Sloth. 
Even after all of our sins, do we still deserve to be forgiven?[/i]

If there is one game I absolutely recommend to anyone seeking a new game, almost every time it is DISTRAINT. At $4.99 for full price and generally less than $1 on frequent sale it is absolutely worth every penny. It's even available on Android and consoles if that is more your style. Honestly the hardest part of describing this game is trying to make it as spoiler-free as possible since the best way to play it is to not deep-dive into reviews or look too much into videos - going in as blind as possible is the way it should be played. It also takes only around 2h to fully complete.

[b]I will however state one content warning:[/b] to those friends who may have difficulties with [spoiler]depression[/spoiler], [spoiler]talk of self-harm or suicide[/spoiler], or [spoiler]grotesque visuals and/or blood[/spoiler] it may be best to avoid playing it, or at least be very aware at the risk of that imagery. This game is heavily psychological and there are moments where it gets very dark and may affect your mental state if you are sensitive to it. Please do not put your mental health at risk. 

With that being said, even with as dark and almost bleak this game may be, it's almost borderline beautiful. There are moments where you can really think about the cruelty of life and yet how important it is to live. Just how easy it is to fall into a depressive repetitive loop and feel unable to escape. The difficulty of trying to face your own personal demons and the struggle to not let them devour you. Or even the most important thought of all: just what is the price you are willing to pay to keep your humanity? Your morality? Your happiness? What price would you pay to manage to live? 
I never expected such a cheap little game I bought purely on whim to be nearly as memorable as it is. I first played this game back in 2017 and even now I still constantly think about it. 

If I had any closing statements to this review it would simply be: please, if you can handle it, give DISTRAINT and the sequel DISTRAINT 2 a chance. They absolutely deserve it.

Thank you, Jesse Makkonen for sharing this beautiful piece of work.

139179218.review:
Play as Price, who's career choice let him into a path he really regrets. Is he facing his inner demons in a positive way or is he losing this battle?

Loved the style of this game. It's pretty dark and basic, and it works. You're being thrown in really awkward situations, strange puzzles, some weird and creepy happenings and lots of it is quite metaphorical.

It's not too heavy on the horror. There are some mild jump scares but the focus goes to the psychological stuff. In the first two chapters, I constantly had the feeling that someone or something was out to get me. Let's say the game does a good job at subverting your expectations.

As for gameplay, it's sort of a point 'n click adventure. You can only walk left and right and go through doors in the background to enter new areas. There's a lot of little pieces of dialog to build the story, but not too much as to keep you from playing.

A wonderful little psychological horror game.
It was a real joy to experience.
Although I don't think the main character would agree.

Distraint: Deluxe Edition is another great psychological horror game.  Lots of life lessons here, adult jokes especially about finances and work life that anyone who has ever worked as a corporate slave might relate to.

The horror effect is well done here.  There are a few jumpscares but not too overwhelming.  The jumpscare here adapts to the moment, so it doesn't appear very randomly.  The BGM also developing the player's emotional. Sometimes there's no music in a certain place and moment to give an eerie vibes. 

For gameplay, it's quite simple for me. Side scrolling with simple puzzle-solving to continue the story. I can say, Distraint: Deluxe Edition emphasizes in story rather than mechanism. Since I played it by controller, I can't find how to swap item list. Eventually I still able to open item menu, but sadly can't swap the item to use. Hopefully, the developer can concern more about controller usage for the next games.

137118785.review:
[b] Addressing the bloody elephant in the room... ;) [/b]

Distraint is a short (~2 hours) game developed by a single person named Jesse Makkonen. Strong essences are kept in small bottles as they say and that's the case here aswell. 

The player takes on the role of Price, a young man working for a company that makes sure people will free their homes if for whatever reason they're not able to pay their debts anymore. The game is mainly composed of 3 such episodes where we have to deliver the bad news to an old widowed lady, a forest recluse and a drug addict. Character development does a good job in making the player empathize with both sides' points of view. Price doesn't like the fact that he has to make people leave their homes and the people don't blame Price (because it's his job at the end of the day) even though they have their own problems to deal with. 

Price doesn't chase riches in a greedy manner such as his bosses do, even though him securing a partnership with the company made him chicken out from his initial goal (after he felt he caused so much suffering, he wanted to quit his job).

The story comes full circle. Years later, Price is told to leave his apartment by a young man who now is heeded not to repeat the same mistakes and knows all that Price went through. 

We get to experience a dark twist in the ending, in tone with the vibe that the rest of the game had. 

The use of sound effects, grimy pixel artwork and gloomy soundtrack emphasize important moments and the mental torment that the main character is going through, even if some moments are really dramatic and feel purposefully exaggerated towards that end. 

[b] Worth getting ? [/b]

YES ! Distraint costs about 80 cents at a sale, it's a total steal even for the full price considering how well put together the whole experience is, even if short. Prepare to solve a few puzzles here and there, most of them are intuitive and make sense within the context. 100% achievements is an easy goal for this game. Buckle up for a rollercoaster of emotions.

133908944.review:
In [i]DISTRAINT[/i] we play as a young man called Price who longs for a better life, one where he is successful and can afford a higher standard of living - because with wealth comes happiness, right? To obtain the desired recognition from his bosses Price has to work hard and complete given tasks of property seizure without asking, doubting, disobeying, showing compassion… but as Price isn't a heartless individual his first assignment shakes him to the core. Questions concerning ethics and morality of his work resurfaces with a growing urgency and his conscience gets exposed to horrid hallucinations. Each step he takes brings him closer to his desired future life… the question is - does he still long for it for such a price?

[i]DISTRAINT[/i] is a pretty good little game. It's a little bit weird to say that I had fun with it, when we consider that it's a psychological horror, but I have enjoyed my two playthroughs and even had a few laughs. The graphic design is rather strange but very appealing, especially the color tinting in different scenes. Music is also fine and helps to create the right mood when you explore, run for your life or just wander drugged up through halls.
Everything in the game is rather simple and yet it manages to deliver disturbing and unpleasant feelings that are closely tied up to our society. Through the character of Price the game holds a mirror to our greedy souls and shows ugly things in it. Whole atmosphere of the game is heavy, unhappy and every time a flicker of hope shows up it gets stamped by	[spoiler]an elephant[/spoiler] to the ground. So, if you are not feeling well, wait a bit before playing it and go find some cute kittens instead. Otherwise I can recommend it to anyone who's not afraid of taking a glance in the mirror.

125644228.review:
Read the FULL Review here (because steam limits how long they can be): https://gemsimov.com/game-reviews/f/distraint---a-review

 Hello everyone, I am the loanshark with a conscience, G.E.M.Simov, a guy with a hat that looks remarkably like a kippah, here to tell you about DISTRAINT… Deluxe Edition?

Gameplay

 DISTRAINT is a 2D side-scrolling Adventure game of the Poin&Click variety, though there is no pointing and clicking. Instead, the Player is presented the WASD buttons as their means of moving around - though the only use comes from A and D, as the environments are all horizontal - as well as the E key for interaction and the Spacebar for access to the Inventory.

 What this game does interestingly is the simplicity with which it operates. The E key interacts with things that are interactable. Things that are interactable have an exclamation point appearing over the Player Character (PC)’s head, whenever the PC is close enough to interact with those things (objects).

 If the Player collects an item, that item will go into the Player’s inventory, which when accessed, can be navigated by using the E key, as the inventory is a wheel with items, with the item currently selected being highlighted and being used to interact with objects and things.

 That means that, to interact with things normally, the Player should go into their inventory and highlight an empty slot, for, otherwise, the PC will attempt to interact with things via the highlighted item.

 And that’s pretty much it. The Player controls the PC, walks around with them, interacts with things and has a grand old time. Naturally, though, this is an Adventure game. Those come with the Stigma of having ludicrously stupid and obtuse puzzles that only get solved via sheer luck or the utilization of a guide. Does DISTRAINT have that issue?

 It almost does, but that is owed up to the lackluster information provided to the Player. Some puzzles feature more than enough information to be obvious, others feature far less information and, as a result, are a little more time-consuming than they really ought to. In any case, though, DISTRAINT shows restraint in the field of ludicrously complex puzzles. That is not wholly good, but it is definitely not bad.

 For what it is - a small, story-focused, visual storytelling empowered Adventure (puzzle-focused) game, this much gameplay is enough. 3/3

Presentation

 DISTRAINT is a game relying on pixel-art to relay its visuals to the Player. In fact, it relies on some very good pixel-art… Though then there are moments when the pixel-art is questionable at best.

 An example of this issue would be the opening room. There’s an elevator door, there are three ordinary doors, there’s stuff in the background that looks very neat, and then there’s the PC. The PC, ladies and gentlemen, looks silly. Goofy, if one will, for while the backgrounds and sets, and overall the areas in which the game takes place are aiming for an appearance that resembles reality - plausible is a good means of describing it. However, the characters all look a lot less plausible. Their bodies and heads are humongous, while their arms and legs are unbelievably thin twigs.

 The best way to describe the ‘human’ characters in this game would be to urge you to imagine a barrel with a big pumpkin on it. On the upper rim of the barrel, where the barrel ends and the pumpkin begins, are attached, on opposite sides, stockings that reach down to the lower rim of the barrel, then there’s another set of stockings attached to the lower rim of the barrel. The head is the pumpkin, the body is the barrel, and the flimsy, thin stockings are arms (upper pair) and legs (lower pair).

 This really bothered me, as I found their appearances so unappealing, so disinteresting and caricature-esque that I was really not interested in playing the game, initially. Fortunately, though, the main focus is slightly skewed towards the environments, so there’s less looking at the characters and more looking at the wondrous backgrounds.

 Though the impressive accomplishments of this game’s Presentation do not stop there. I will call upon a game I’ve reviewed recently - The Desolate Hope - and use it as a comparison. In The Desolate Hope, there was an effect similar to that of damaged film. It was monstrously intrusive and straining for the eye, and there was no option to reduce or remove it.

 In DISTRAINT, there is something similar. There is film grain, constantly present, growing more intense in some situations. That film grain is very well integrated into the ‘visuals of the game’, making it seem as though it is a mandatory part of the game and the experience it is providing. Not only that, it is quite tame AND one can set its intensity in the options menu.

 Right, more on that - the game features a very neat main menu AND an options menu. Strangely enough, the game uses the WASD keys to navigate the menu, and the E key to select things, though that’s related to the Gameplay. What’s neat is that THERE IS A TEXT-BOX stating that this is so. In many smaller, indie games - such as DISTRAINT - the control scheme is some wildly weird thing, and the menu operates according to these wildly weird principles, so the Player needs to guess which buttons do what.

 This clever means of presentation persists throughout the entire game. As mentioned, interactable objects are highlighted by an exclamation point when one is close enough to interact with them. There’s also the fact that the font, as well as the size of the text, is very reasonable.

 Then we could get to the scares, as this is supposedly a scary game. The scares are all mostly visual, with accompanying audio cues, though the audio cues are not monstrously loud, coming in out of a very quiet audio scene. They are just sounds joining in the cacophony of the game. The visual aspect of them is far more interesting, and I’ll keep it at that.

 More on the audio - the sound effects of the game are very crisp. That could be because they’re a bit loud, or it could be because through their crisp loudness they work towards creating an atmosphere. An atmosphere of suspense and unease. Some objects let out their own sounds which grow louder the closer the PC is to those objects and fainter the further away they are, and then there are some sounds that seemingly originate from certain objects, but there is no visual indicator that it is so - in addition to that, they are not constant, so the imply that SOMETHING has happened whenever they occur.

 That creates tension and unease in the Player, which is the best way of going about making a horror game - none of this stinky jump-scare garbage - and DISTRAINT does it quite well.

 In addition to that, of course, the music is very fitting. Painfully drawn strings, almost like screams, though very subdued and distant… It isn’t something truly exceptional, but it is more than just okay.

 One other thing this game does well is the subversion of expectation. I’ll leave that up to you to experience, if you do decide to experience it.

 So, even with the issue of the weird-looking characters, and the issue of some very weird word presences in sentences (as far as I’m aware of she can’t do that - the “of” is needless), I would like to say that DISTRAINT’s appearance is very proper. 2/3

[Skipping stuff to fit in Steam]

Conclusion

8/10. DISTRAINT is an impressively good game that suffers from a slightly repulsive character design flaw, which turns people off of playing it before even buying it. The game is, however, great. It is incredibly poignant and important, and I’d urge everyone to play it, with the exception of squeamish people and those who are afflicted with trauma from past events in their lives involving suicide.

Full review here: https://gemsimov.com/game-reviews/f/distraint---a-review

[Pay-to-Play] I was very lucky to win this game + the sequel of it: DISTRAINT 2 & and DISTRAINT 2 Soundtrack from a wonderful friend ^_^ While horror games are not my cup of tea, I like the looks of this game :D It is in 2D side-scroller and Pixel graphics ish. Overall this game will take about 2 hours to complete

I am thankful there isnt major jumpscares or is too..graphic/scary, however there are still elements of horror..especially the background sound which really brings up the creepy/horror ambience.

It is rather "mild" as it is not in 3D form however the sound really creeped me out at times. However be warned that some scenes are still quite gorey.

You move with WASD and 'E' to interact. And 'Space' to open up your inventory.

So you played as a character named Price. (oh..the irony of the name); I would say he's something like a property agent, to seize the houses of others..either because they couldnt afford to pay their taxes/mortgage..or because the rich wanted to build infrastructure over their properties.. oh f**k the Capitalism!

So alas..those poor souls..This game takes you through the consequences of Price's actions 

There are savepoints even though you generally wouldnt die..except for the first part when you are being chased by an elephant. Other than that, its a safe-run.

I would generally advice to follow this guide closely: https://www.walkthroughking.com/text/distraint.aspx
If you wish to obtain all 16 achievements. And if you miss them, you might have to playthrough the whole thing again

I did miss one achievement however it was still in the earlier parts, so I had to just re-play it briefly.

This game is very impactful and I hope you'll enjoy it as much as I do. 

Uncover what price does Price have to pay..
and..everything comes at a Price..

122838773.review:
As is typical with some indie games, the art and audio are fantastic, but it lacks in a couple other important departments: puzzles, and story+lore.

What I didn’t like was that horrible things that happened to the protagonist were not earned. He didn’t do anything terrible, and was just a regular guy, doing a job that nobody liked to do, all while being far more considerate of others than most other people typically would be. Honestly, the mental-imagery-manifested-in-the-real-world stuff felt really forced and just broke my immersion. Some problems with lazy writing, like yelling “what the hell”, didn’t help.

The other problem was the puzzles, as they ranged from either too simplistic to being a bit of a chore, and they lacked any real challenge. There’s nothing wrong with this by itself, because sometimes a game can sacrifice mechanics and challenge to focus on being a narrative “experience”. But given that I thought the narrative was weak and a little too sweaty, I think this hurt the game more than anything.

I understand the developer put this together in only 3 months, which is remarkable, but it’s still something I can’t recommend. It just didn’t have any emotional impact that stayed with me.

The story will be about Price - a young man who works as a collector. A person who is tired of poverty and wants to live comfortably. A man whose priorities in life are broken after he kicks an old woman out of her house because of her debts...

[b]Pros:[/b][list]
[*]+ Interesting visual style
[*]+ Game made by one person
[*]+ Achievements
[*]+ Trading cards
[*]+ Two versions of the game in one

[b]Minuses:[/b]
[*]- Achievements do not work in the deluxe version - but they opened smoothly in the classic version.
[*]- No gamepad support
[*]- Elephant
[*]- Mushrooms[/list]

[b]Total:[/b]
Excellent psychological indie horror story. Attacks of psychedelia are smoothly inscribed in the surrounding world, and do not appear to the player as something superfluous.
The game has simple controls that allow you to immerse yourself in the game using only one hand. Unfortunately, the game does not support gamepads.
A short game session allows you to collect all the achievements in one playthrough. Thus adding another game to the "perfectionist" showcase.
I recommend this project for purchase, and also draw your attention to other games of the developer, which also turned out to be interesting and unusual.

120018515.review:
As is typical with some indie games, the art and audio are fantastic, but it lacks in a couple other important departments: puzzles, and story+lore.

What I didn’t like was that horrible things that happened to the protagonist were not earned. He didn’t do anything terrible, and was just a regular guy, doing a job that nobody liked to do, all while being far more considerate of others than most other people typically would be. Honestly, the mental-imagery-manifested-in-the-real-world stuff felt really forced and just broke my immersion. Some problems with lazy writing, like yelling “what the hell”, didn’t help.

The other problem was the puzzles, as they ranged from either too simplistic to being a bit of a chore, and they lacked any real challenge. There’s nothing wrong with this by itself, because sometimes a game can sacrifice mechanics and challenge to focus on being a narrative “experience”. But given that I thought the narrative was weak and a little too sweaty, I think this hurt the game more than anything.

I understand the developer put this together in only 3 months, which is remarkable, but it’s still something I can’t recommend. It just didn’t have any emotional impact that stayed with me.

118854002.review:
I enjoyed this psychological-horror adventure game. 
It's about a guy who works for a financial institution. His job is to evict people from their homes, when they can't pay the rent or the mortgage. 
It is very minimalistic, the graphics and game play is very modest. The puzzles are easy. All this is intentional, the focus of this game is all about the story, about the emotional impact on the player and about the message that is given. The guy perceives the dispair of those evicted people, and starts to question his line of work, feeling remorse feelings that are creeping more and more. He even begins to lose his mind and to see paranormal scenes. 
The game is very thought provoking and relaxing. It makes you stop and reflect on the scenes you just perceived. 
Hovewer, I simply must mention a big shortcoming that this game has. 
In the third chapter the protagonist has to search for a person to be evicted in a building. The building is nothing less then a labyrint with all the doors and secret doors. To make things worse, the chapter is designed that you have to take some hallucinogenic drug in order to enter secret doors - and you have to find your way fast because the effect of the drug is limited to 7,8 seconds or so. There are 3 or 4 such sequences. If you fail to enter the right door, you often have to start over to the first sequence. I must admit, that part nearly ruined the game for me. Because it's just bad/irrational level design, and it's completely disjointed from the rest of the game. 
I had to consult a you tube guide to pass that chapter, and doing so breaks the immersion to the game. 
Many people complained about that part of the game, and many people even quit the game in that point. 
But, I will give this game a positive review nontheless because of how deep and thought proviking it is. 
I hope the game maker doesn't repeat such obvious mistakes in his future titles.

115615455.review:
Length <2hrs

Distraint is a 2D Side Scrolling Horror game, in which the player will be searching for items to progress. The game tells the story of a Debt Collector who is attempting to become a partner at a large firm, but the actions he needs to do to get there slowly crushes him. Each location the player visits they need to remove someone vulnerable from their house.

The gameplay is a lot of narrative interactions, and item hunting. In order to remove the person from their house, the player will need to complete a task for them, this will involve going deeper into the maps. The items the player needs are easy to find, with only a few occasions did I become lost. That was mainly because in the last level you can shift reality, and in the shift I did not explore all rooms.

The story is the biggest selling point of the game. We start the game hopeful of the future and watch as your character is slowly broken each time he has to evict a tenant. We watch the character trying to reason with the situation. Each tenant does not put up a fight, or blame the player for their actions, instead they are dejected asking for more time or support with their situation.

I won’t spoil the story but it is interesting and worth the experience.

Distraint is a great story and a fun game, it is really worth the play. At times you may get lost and I would advise a guide if needed, the puzzles are simple and the few action scenes offer little challenge. The game is simply worth it for the story alone and has been one of the most interesting narrative games I’ve played yet.

There is a sequel to the game, and while I do not find it as good as the first it is still worth experiencing. It will leave the ending in a more hopeful situation.

If you want to have a look at the gameplay my video is right below:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9IW2AxVSBiw

If you are looking for other horror games with great stories all the ones I’ve played are in my curator page:

https://store.steampowered.com/curator/41770172/

112293114.review:
Distraint is a psychological horror, move & interact game.

You play as Price, who's a mentally weak dude that has the job of delivering eviction notices to people. You'll go to a location, solve some puzzles, some spooky stuff will happen, then you get a little cutscene, and move on to the next location.

There's some enjoyable stuff such as the art, horror aspects, & tripping out.

It's not a bad game, there just isn't much to it.

The puzzles are very simplistic. Most of them are simply: find object, take it somewhere, and use it. You'll never have a large inventory so there will rarely be a question of where something goes. There're also some poorly written puzzles. For instance, one part you need to find flowers for someone, and somehow Price knows they're in a locked room he has never been in before.

The slow moving speed is an issue that causes parts to drag out longer than necessary. Later on in the game there are segments where you move much faster, so there's no reason why that couldn't have been the default moving speed or been given an option to make that the default moving speed.

The characters are all one note caricatures that lack any sort of depth, which removes the emotion you might feel if these people had been fleshed out in some meaningful way. You're supposed to feel bad for old lady because she's old & nice. You're supposed to feel bad for guy in woods because he doesn't want to give up his cabin. You're supposed to feel bad for drugged up, dishonest party guy..... Wait, I didn't feel bad at all for kicking that piece of garbage out. Your employers are all super greedy and care about nothing but money. The problem here though is all of that is shown to be in Price's head. We never learn if they're actually good/bad/indifferent. In fact, the only thing we do learn about them shows them in a positive light towards the end of the game.

Lastly, I'm not sure what the point of this is or what message I'm supposed to take away. It seems like it wants to say greed, money, capitalism are bad, but completely fails to deliver that point. Am I truly to believe that the creator of this or anyone reading this would enter into a rental agreement with someone for X amount of money per month, have that person pay them less than X/nothing, and would be perfectly happy allowing that person to continue living there? Would never give them a notice that they need to start paying the agreed upon amount? Would never evict them if they continued failing to pay?

Is the message that jobs that deliver bad news for the continuation of life/business should be done away with? Price didn't cause old lady to not pay her rent. Price didn't choose to build a highway that goes through where the guy's cabin is (which he was given restitution for if I recall correctly). Price didn't cause party guy to not have money to pay rent or procrastinate on finding a new place to live when he clearly knew ahead of time to look for a new place. He's simply the bearer of bad news due to other people's failures/extraneous situations.

The only points that the game seems to make is that mentally weak people shouldn't take jobs that require mental fortitude and that businesses constantly have to put up with people attempting to bargain with them over their own failures/issues.

Distraint is ok if you're looking for something cheap to kill some time on. Other than that, there's no reason to play this.

109204214.review:
It is a neat little game about regret and the most extreme outcome it can take, if you don't listen to yourself and let outside influences dictate your decisions. The dialogue/monologue was a little bit ham fisted at times, but overall very good.

I liked the representation, especially for the fact that this game was made by one person alone. I am not a big horror fan and I wasn't too happy about the few jump scares, especially the audible ones. But I really liked the sound overall. Rarely have I seen audible represenation of ambience done this well in a small project like this.

The visuals are quite interesting and reminded me a little bit of Braid. The sprites are well done, but at times I felt that the post FX/filters were too much and made the environments hard to read.

The playtime is short, but to me it felt longer than that, in the best possible way. The scenic changes are plenty and the ideas put into this game are very interesting, while also very well executed for the most part.

I really enjoyed my time with this game. A lot more than I expected actually, since I am not a fan of horror, which turned out to fall on the wayside the more you get into this game.

If I had to rate it, I would give it 78/100. Totally worth getting if you can overlook gripes with a game to experience something different.

104930047.review:
[b]"Distraint" is a small indie side scrolling adventure with a unique artistic style and good technical elements. It is visually gorgeous with fantastic music and surreal, dark atmosphere. But everything else is a mess. Puzzles are unaspiring and gameplay has nothing interesting to offer. It just forces you to go from point A to point B while many times there is absolutely no logic at the protagonist's actions. The story is too simplistic, symbolic and cliché and the characters are so flat that you cannot attach emotionally to them. Finally and worst, I'm sure that the creator had some good intentions but the political message I received at the end is morally problematic.


Manometer: 3/10[/b]


The good
- Unique artistic approach. Nice pixelated 2d graphics with a unique chromatic palette and some nice visual effects. It is gorgeous.
- Good mysterious, surreal atmosphere. Sometimes it is calm and sometimes it gets really dark. It switches from a dream to a nightmare and vice versa.
- Fantastic music. It is the strongest part of the game and really enhances the atmosphere.
- Simple but nice sound design that fits the visual aesthetics.
- This long narrow format is an interesting choice. It is unique and could symbolize the linear path of the protagonist's life.

The bad
- The narrative is too shallow and cliché. Dialogues are extremely simplistic. The story is naive with a lot of thin symbolisms like it is written for children who have to understand. The ending is as cliché as it gets.
- Characters are flat. They are caricatures that player cannot love or emotionally attach to them. You won't even care about the fate of old miss Goodwin.
- Sometimes your actions make no sense at all. You just do them because there is nothing else to do. I don't understand why the protagonist gives that meat for cooking while knowing that it is human flesh. I don't understand how he is aware of the flower inside the locked room in the nursing home. And these are not the only examples that lack logic.
- Gameplay has nothing interesting to offer. It just forces you to go from point A to point B. Puzzles are simplistic, uninspiring and unchallenging. I would have no problem if this was a more movie-like game without puzzles at all. But since puzzles are included, I have to judge them.
- I felt that it often gets pretentious. Most horror scenes (these with the blood and the slaughtering) have no real reason of existence and they are there just to impress the player. It tries too hard to become a horror game as it packs some silly jump scares and some random "scary" sounds too.
- I'm sure that the developer had good intentions, but I'm not sure about the political correctness of the outcome. I mean, the perspective it puts you feels wrong right from the beginning. The protagonist is the man who seizes properties and not his victims. We watch his life. His nightmares, thoughts and regrets. So what is the teaching? Do I have to believe that these "wanna be golden boys" are good guys forced to do bad things while feeling guilty deep inside? Why they don't just pick another job? Are they just naive? Do I have to feel sorry about them when they receive their fat monthly guilty paycheck? If I feel sorry about them, then what should I feel about the real victims?

103330040.review:
I don't get the hype, it just isn't very good.  The idea is solid (if cliched), what do you lose if you "sell your soul" by putting money above morality, but the execution is awful.

Price (you) is essentially a  bailiff, tossing out those who for whatever reason have been told to leave their homes, but is painted from the start as reluctant as he knows people are being unfairly treated, but given he has absolutely no say in these matters other than to quit (and let someone else do it) then the whole morality issue is a non-starter.  Each character is flat and one-note so we don't have any reason to care about them.

Then there's the gameplay issues, it doesn't matter what type of atmosphere you are going for, waddling slowly back and forth through through long corridors is just boring, especially when you can't tell if the end is a door or not.  And logic failings, why would Price be willing to pick up random human flesh and pretend it's beef to a cook when he hasn't even been told the cook has anything he wants in return?  When looking for a flower why would he even consider asking a nurse to open a set of bars to he can get the flower from inside even though he has no knowledge that it is in there?  When just wanting to get through one more job to get home apparently it's a good idea so say "hey there's some random checmical in a drugs lab, let's get high".

I'm sorry but flat characters, illogical puzzles and odd motivations all point to an author who had an end point in mind but was too lazy to work out a coherent way to get there.

101856259.review:
One of those games you pick up on some sale that's under a dollar and completely obliterates your expectations. Distraint is a dark, side-scrolling adventure game with p-n-click adventure elements with a great emphasis on exploration and light puzzle solving. There's a strong narrative carried by sharp writing that keeps the adventure moving. The game is beautifully detailed with some wonderful pixel art, the lighting is particularly well done. There's a strange beauty to it, despite borrowing from the iconic horror of the Silent Hill series. In sum, a touching adventure with a big heart and engrossing character work. Glad to see that it got a sequel, will be checking that out shortly.

Minor complaint:
-the third act introduces a timing element to the puzzle solving that threw me into a loop. Not saying I hated it, but it does have the drawback of introducing some unpleasant backtracking. this was the only part of the game where I became aware of the movement speed
-while the visuals are fantastic, I do wish the audio was of equal quality but there just isn't enough of it (sound effects, music)

side tasks

psychedelic
hidden achievements
worth playing again: for  the hidden things I believe most players will miss, for the story itself, AND for the gameplay

CONS: 
Relatively short gameplay, but sufficient, and not too short

WORTH PLAYING AGAIN?

101129042.review:
DISTRAINT is a well-made 2D pixelated psychological horror experience. The atmosphere and especially sound are really on point. And there’re plenty of jump scares, that somehow feel cheap but at the same time don’t, because they’re well done. The story mostly deals with guilt and regret. There are also puzzles to solve, requiring you to collect and use items and the right places.
From a technical standpoint, I also like that while there’s an updated, Deluxe version, the entire original version is still available if you want. You can freely choose the version, and the save is compatible with both! Just a free upgrade, while maintaining the original available.
The game is short, around 2-3 hours, but if you like the genre, it’s a good pick on sale. You can see the dedication poured into it.

100711462.review:
These are two small games DISTRAINT: Deluxe Edition & DISTRAINT 2. Each of these games can be finished in a single sitting.

The first game is a story about a disturbed man who's drive for success causes him to go mad. A man named Price who works for a real estate company has a job that has him going around to peoples houses and evicting them. The story is about how guilty he feels about it and how it's driving him to insanity. The horror in these games reminds me of Silent Hill and the puzzles where super easy, at least for me. The second game is the conclusion to the first one and answers some of the questions that were left over from the first. Although it wasn't as scary as the first one and the games story was a bit more on the nose with it's theme of a man fighting his own demons.

I liked these games, the first one more so. If you want to play them then play both together one after the other. Play the first one on Deluxe Edition instead of the default one. GG

99663694.review:
Leafy's simple review - #36

Who, seriously, never enjoyed a big-headed protagonist? 

With the grim, dark, unsettling art style that the developer, Jesse Makkonen, took with 'Distraint', the gameplay is rather simplistic and rooted in adventure tropes such as collecting keys, tools and items to get by. 

Character design is interesting with a play off the calm and collected debt collector (well....MOSTLY calm) when the player starts to realize how unhinged some of the others are in the game - particularly McDade, Bruton and Moore, a trio of money-hungry bosses set out on twisting your world into play dough.

While the narrative is a little all around the place, the feeling of psychological horror and perhaps, mental disorder, really comes into play rather quickly with an excellent soundtrack. Despite having a slow-walking character, there are moments of story telling brilliance which shows through the at time witty, and at other times, intelligent, use of dialogue.

But are you one for simple mechanics and dreary atmosphere? Or do you find yourself ensnared by the grainy, film visuals? This short little adventure is definitely worth it in my opinion and one which may change the way you see property seizures, out in the darker corners of the world.

98474288.review:
This game was such a huge dissapointment and overall very frustrating to play. 

visually, it looks cool (although the cartoonishly large heads do take away from the horror of it. I understand this was a stylistic choice, but its one that doesn't really work or make sense to me.). 

The audio is neat I guess but it gets kinda cheesey in the woods with the screeeech sound at regular intervals that is far more annoying and ear piercing than it is creepy. 

As for the gameplay mechanics, this is one of the first places where this game fails to me. it takes farrrr too long to walk from place to place and this game has SO much walking. I would understand this if the walking was meant to be a nerve racking aspect, but when you are really just walking to find that one thing you missed, backtracking between rooms, cabins, and hospitals it gets very frustrating. A bit of a spoiler warning but there is a part where you are in a nightmare with a room full of the old woman you evicted walking around as different variations of herself with one crying in the middle. I actually had to look up the walkthrough for this part as I thought I had soft locked myself or something. In reality, the thing I was missing (after spending 30 minutes trying to figure out what was wrong) was that I was trying to talk to the crying woman from the wrong side. That's right. In this game some characters are approachable from either side and then some you need to be approaching them from the right side and be facing them properly. This mechanic was not explained nor introduced in any way which is strange considering the game doesn't at all mind absolutely ruining the experience everytime you save with the same dialogue "game saved, whatever that means". 

I tried. I really tried to give this game a second and third chance. After thinking I was softlocked but actually just missing a key mechanic that was never explained I got to another puzzle. A timed puzzle. And oh lord this is where I just lost my shit.  Maybe I'm just bad at puzzles, but considering im not the first in the reviews to be frustrated by this, I don't think it's just an issue with me. Not only is the puzzle timed, but it is also beyond confusing as the layout of the rooms and passages between rooms is terrible. Hallways or doors will lead to the right and then have a door in that room that goes back to the left without having to walk anywhere. It's confusing and frustrating, and having a timer that lasts about 5 seconds that you need to get through half of the doors doesn't help. What was at first a cool mechanic was then a frustrating obstacle that left me wondering what the hell I was doing wrong. 

Now for the plot and story which was something that I was actually interested in at first. As someone who is a big fan of critiques of capitalism and/or guilt this story interested me at first. But the symbolism, dialogue, and execution of this was so incredibly lackluster that I found myself groaning in boredom and having to quit playing the game entirely. This paired with the amount of slow, long walking that you have to do,  it becomes unbearable. 

Final Thoughts:
I'm sure some may enjoy this game, but I absolutely did not. I can see positive aspects like the visuals and atmosphere, but the rest of it is just so bland and uninspired. The only thing that sets it apart from a generic visual novel is the style with the big heads, but if you really want that kind of art style you'd probably find more success and interesting stories with big headed characters from edgy GachaLife tiktok compilations.

96373560.review:
Since playing the “Devil Went Through Here” series, I’ve sort of fallen in love with the horror-adventure genre and I’m happy to report that this game has only added fuel to the fire.

Before I get ahead of myself, I should address the elephant in the room: I’m not sure I understand the artistic direction, here. Like, why do all the characters look like toddlers wearing poopy diapers? Maybe there’s something deeper, here… Perhaps it’s a comment on the infantile, self-interested nature of greed? Maybe it’s a reflection of Price’s childlike hero-worship directed toward the heads of the firm where he works and his attempt to grow and gain power in a world that tends to regard him as meek and inconsequential? I don’t have a clue. It kind of just looks like everyone in the game shit their pants. Whatever.

Aside from the weirdness, [i]Distraint[/i] proved to be a solid experience. While it curated some moments that will haunt me for a long time, for sure, it also knew how to be fun. (Throwing a drug-fueled eviction party for a soon-to-be homeless renter comes to mind.)

The story was somewhat simplistic but still thought-provoking. I mean, I never thought I’d play a horror game about bankers or whatever, so I have no standard to measure it against. It still freaked me out, that’s for sure: by the end, I was filled with a sense of dread because I knew that that if I was in the same situations as Price, I’d probably wind up doing the same fucking thing.

And that’s the reason I have to recommend this one: the kind of horror that makes me look inward and examine myself is exactly the kind of horror I strive to find. So, if you’re in the market for a horror story with a unique premise and are willing to make allowances for an… interesting… art style, you can’t go wrong with this one. I am personally excited to see what [i]Distraint 2[/i] has in store.

95638780.review: Okay, I wouldn't normally change a review based upon its sequel, but this is definitely a special case. While I originally thought that this game was too gruesome for me (at first I thought of it only as allegorical, and was ok with it, but as the game progressed, I started to feel like it was gratuitous, like thinking "what's the most disgusting thing I can show here?" and going all out there, even when it didn't fit the story at that point), and that the ending was [spoiler] awful and depressing (it's usually a deal-breaker for me when you are forced, without possibility of refusal or any kind of actual choice, to kill someone. [/spoiler]), the sequel changes things in an unexpected way. So I'm changing my review to positive, with one very important caveat: don't play just this one, play its sequel too. Take both of them as two chapters of the same story, and not as separate games, because they are not. Don't stick with the ending to this one, because it's nowhere near done; in a way, the first game is just the prologue to a very deep story, with an important message. Together, they are very much worth your time and money.

91419067.review:
Di-os. 
Me encanta este tipo de juegos, narrativos, point and click (aunque aquí lo haces con las teclas, pero el espíritu es el mismo). Juegos como The Last Door, que cuentan una historia profunda, con sus cambios, sus capítulos, sus personajes entrañables, etc. 
Este juego ha sido una sorpresa. Lo tenía en deseados desde hace un tiempo y ha sido ahora, mucho tiempo después cuando lo he comprado. 
La historia es muy entretenida y desde el principio vas viendo venir esas trazas de crítica a la burocracia, al capital, etc. El estilo artístico y el sonido van también muy unidos a esta sensación de decadencia, de tristeza o más bien de apatía y disociación. 
Conforme el personaje va entrando en esa espiral psicótica y se va encontrando con sus decisiones morales, la historia parece que da un giro de 180 grados y que también lo vas a ver venir. Pero ahí está lo bueno. Este juego sorprende (y para bien) a cada paso que das. De lo que parecía un capítulo de relleno muy sencillo para terminar, acaba saliendo un cierre para la historia brutal, que yo desde luego no he visto venir, pero que explica muchas cosas. 
En definitiva, un juego recomendadísimo, gran historia, gran estilo narrativo, puzles sencillos que no dificultan el juego ni te sacan de la narración. 10/10

This is a very good indie psychological horror game.
Now there is no combat,no cheap jump scares and nothing of that crapola you see in most of the AAA titles.This is a story of depression,anxiety and coping with the modern way of life.I am playing DISTRAINT 2 and went back to see what I wrote when I finished this one and I was surprised I didn't write a review when I finished this.This game does a good job in describing these mental issues with very simple and clear dialogues so people who are not suffering from these issues can get a clearer picture on what a person goes through,all though if I am honest only someone who is going through these things can really relate to this topic.Many horror games use symbolism to describe mental illness so in my opinion the dev wanted to make this topic clearer through very clear dialogues.
I love the art style in this game,it is beautiful and yet in a way disturbing at many levels.The music is stunning for a small developer and the sound is also well done and adds to the atmosphere.
This game is a proof you don't need to spend big money to make a good horror game because for me it is what we don't see and don't know that is really frightening.

89792108.review:
Distraint: Deluxe Edition (2015)

Distraint - "the seizure of someone’s property in order to obtain payment of rent or other money owed". You play as a man named Price who is send out by his company to seize the properties of three people and by doing so they make you a partner in their company. Lets face it, its not a pretty job to do. Price starts to realise he is destroying people's lives and it starts to slowly chip away at him to the point of hysteria.

The setting of the game is dark and twisted, you feel uneasy with this game never knowing when something creepy might pop up. The game is not very long but its worth a shot if you like creepy and unsettling games.

8/10

89632197.review:
This game saved my life.

I am 43.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiralling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

87960928.review:
Me encanta el planteamiento de Distraint: un juego de terror psicológico en el que el protagonista (Price) se atormenta constantemente por las decisiones poco éticas que se ve obligado a tomar en su trabajo como embargador, debatiéndose constantemente si merece la pena vivir así y cuestionándose cada vez más su propia moral.

El juego hace un muy buen trabajo para que empatices con Price. Te presenta al personaje a la perfección en tan solo veinte minutos y fuera de lo narrativo, el juego muestra la jugabilidad y las mecánicas de forma clara y concisa en tiempo récord. Sin embargo, también deja ver sus fallos casi de inmediato:

La ambientación sonora para los momentos de intriga y tensión está muy bien lograda, el problema es que SUENA TODO EL RATO o bien en escenas en las que simplemente no pega una ambientación tan creepy. Además, los puzles son demasiado simples, lo que le quita bastante gracia a la jugabilidad. Sin embargo, estos dos fallos son minucias, aun más si los comparas con el mayor error del que padece la obra: el desarrollo narrativo.

Distraint es una buena historia mal contada y esconde un mensaje que no sabe como ser transmitido. Lo que hace el juego es restregarte la moraleja de la historia a través de alucinaciones, apariciones fantasmales y pesadillas que surgen de la mismísima nada (y eso sin mencionar los momentos gore que no tienen razón de ser a parte de demostrar lo  """E D G Y""" que es la trama y... en serio; ¿QUÉ LÓGICA TIENE LA PARTE EN LA QUE USAS LA CARNE DE UN CADÁVER TRITURADO  PARA ALIMENTAR A UNA RESIDENCIA DE ANCIANOS? No tiene nada que ver con la forma de ser del personaje, con el tono de la obra y muchísimo menos con su mensaje. Por suerte, esta es la única parte del juego en la que ocurre algo semejante).
Y no solo eso; el simbolismo de Distraint es tan pobre que casi parece una broma (no paraba de reirme con la parte del elefante. Otro momento estúpido sacado de la nada simplemente para impactar).

Ya que estamos, otro problema que tiene la historia es que roza el sobredramatismo en su tramo final y a pesar de que la esperadísima decisión final que toma Price tampoco tiene sentido teniendo en cuenta el intenso debate interno al que se ha sometido a lo largo del juego, el final me parece lo mejor que tiene que ofrecer Distraint (No porque se acabe XD, sino porque es una forma muy inteligente, efectiva y sorprendente de terminar la historia).

Es una pena no poder recomendar Distraint a pesar de sus brillantes pero escasos aciertos narrativos y su precioso apartado artístico/sonoro. No es un juego horrible -ni muchísimo menos- pero sí es una obra arruinada por la necesidad de impactar con escenas oscuras o """A D U L T A S""" y por la incapacidad de contar una historia como Dios manda.

87090270.review:
Right off the bat, I'll just say that DISTRAINT is a very mild horror game so don't expect being too scared. 
Personally, I liked it for this. 
It isn't like "omg this is too scary. i cant play this" but its just "ok im kinda nervous but lets do this"

+ Really good art style and the Deluxe edition adds more atmospheric lighting, which really added to the experience
+ The game makes good use of "stillness". It uses the protagonists house as a break from the main game. I always felt safe and more relaxed there (especially with the good atmosphere and sound-effects, as you can hear traffic) and this creates an effective contrast between the horror segments.
+ Good attention to detail. The protagonist comments on almost everything when you try to combine objects. It was funny at times. I really appreciated this detail.
+ One thing that I recommend to do, is to replay the game. Trust me, it will become abundantly clear with some of the details, especially at the beginning.

- Personally, I felt the game got kind-of silly in the [spoiler] care home [/spoiler] part of the game. The protagonist straight up serves [spoiler] cooked human flesh to an old lady [/spoiler] and there is little consequence because of it, even though the protagonist feels very ashamed and horrible for his other actions. I thought that it would be incorporated into the story more, but it really isn't. Was this dark humor? It just breaks the story and immersion for me, personally.

Other than that, I really recommend this. It's a short but entertaining game. It isn't breath taking or amazingly good, but it's still fun.

85142232.review:
I was expecting a Papers Please, Simple Story - Alex, or even Presentable Liberty. I don't mind walking simulators or some trial and error; as long as the story is good. What I got was a 30 minute story stretched over more than an hour ("puzzles" or what not took me a while) with no real point?

The story is, and this is NOT a spoiler, iTs ScArY because he feels gUiLtY because he's blinded by GrEeD. You show up do the bad thing and get the spooky horror shit. This isn't Fran Bow, he's not especially a nut case aside from the guilt=horror, so what's the point?

One highlight is the inventory which I've never seen, and while put off by it at first, I found it to be very easy to use and made the event system better. I don't like calling them puzzles as they are just a series of do the one random thing and it will allow the story to progress.

Which does bring me to my last frustration with the game which is action boxes, the relative location you have to be to use X on Y or talk to X character. Often times they are obnoxiously specific, not horrible, but sometimes you have to stand on top of a character and sometimes you have to be a full character away, sometimes you need to face a character and sometimes you don't.

These combined with the weird progression system made even my second achievements run feel jittery and annoying though the sequences weren't nearly as bad, so I might recommend a guide to progress through the game more smoothly.

TL:DR
Not much story, "puzzles" are largely random sequence events, looks cool but not much else.

[b]Early Review[/b]

It feels like this game actively hates the player.
[list]
[*]Cheap jump scares

[/list]

83482918.review:
[h1]Pros y contras[/h1]
[b][u]Aspectos positivos[/u]:[/b]
• Una historia atípica, cruda, oscura que deja un mensaje muy claro.
• Un apartado visual embellecido por su pixel art e iluminación.
• Situaciones muy extrañas que impresionan.
• Todo esto junto a una excelente calidad sonora forman una muy buena atmósfera de terror psicológico.

[b][u]Aspectos negativos[/u]:[/b]
• El añadido de algún puzle podría haber hecho más variada la experiencia.
• La navegación por el menú principal me resultó un tanto incómoda.

[h1]Desarrollo[/h1]
Distraint es una experiencia que busca dejar un mensaje. No necesita más que su bello pixel art, oscuro y bien trabajado y dos dimensiones para incomodarte, hacerte sentir mal y captar completamente tu atención hasta que termines la aventura.
Considero que destaca principalmente en dos elementos. Su corte narrativo y como lo presenta y su apartado artístico. Price, quien es el protagonista al cual controlamos, es un empleado dispuesto a vender su humanidad a cambio de alcanzar la cima. En el proceso, a raíz de la culpa, experimentará alucinaciones o tendrá pesadillas las cuales serán uno de los principales elementos de terror psicológico que podremos presenciar. El juego consigue darte algún que otro sobresalto y hacer que sientas en todo momento que [i]las cosas no están bien[/i] gracias a situaciones mórbidas (que pueden llegar a ser chocantes al ser tan repentinas) o el extraño comportamiento de los personajes. Además, algunos de ellos dejan entrever cierta humanidad, por ejemplo, Price con sentimientos de culpa o preocupación, por lo que es fácil ponerse en los zapatos de algunos o sentir pena por otros. Por el contrario, habrá personajes que dejarán muy expuesta la ausencia de su humanidad, por lo que será fácil detestarlos. En resumen, su historia me encantó, no es para nada típica, deja un mensaje muy claro, tiene un final inesperado y resulta ser bastante cruda y oscura. Esta es la segunda vez que lo juego, habiendo dejado pasar un año entre medias y reconozco que consiguió volverme a sorprender en varios puntos.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2340284356
Su pixel art es precioso y tan oscuro como su historia. La música en muchas partes será reemplazada por sonidos extraños que pareciesen provenientes de otro mundo o un silencio incómodo. El hecho de que no sean fáciles de interpretar, es para que estemos alerta ante lo desconocido y preparados para lo que sea que venga. La combinación entre sus situaciones raras, apartado visual oscuro, sonidos irreconocibles y una historia cruda, forman una excelente atmósfera de terror psicológico. Te das cuenta que estás ante una buena ambientación, cuando consiguen darte un sobresalto sin necesidad de emplear un monstruo. En este caso, estoy haciendo un poco de trampa ya que no solo había uno, sino tres de ellos, pero disfrazados de personas normales (un tanto calvas).

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2340279253
Esta resultó ser para mí una experiencia bastante cinematográfica, gracias a las transiciones entre capítulos, que resultan ser un fundido en negr0 muy prolongado, las franjas n3gras que ocupan una gran (gran) porción de la parte superior e inferior de la pantalla, una excelente calidad sonora y una iluminación increíble. Me gustaron mucho todos estos detalles.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2340318342
Jugablemente es muy simple, por lo que se deja bastante en claro que lo que realmente debe tener peso, son los puntos que señalé previamente. Habrá que buscar una serie de elementos en los distintos capítulos y deducir en donde usarlos (muy al estilo de una aventura gráfica en este aspecto, aunque mucho menos rebuscado como acostumbran la gran mayoría de los títulos de este género). Quizás, la implementación de algún que otro puzle no hubiese estado de más, ya que es un juego que se presta a ello. Al ser tan corto (mi primera partida la superé en alrededor de 3 horas) y tan interesante en el resto de sus elementos, no se hace repetitivo, pero si creo que hubiese hecho más variada la experiencia.
Su dificultad es bastante baja, en el sentido de que no cuesta demasiado interpretar lo que se debe hacer. A lo sumo, con lo que se podría llegar a tener mayores inconvenientes, es en el hallazgo de algún elemento que se necesite para avanzar, pero no debería suponer un esfuerzo muy elevado o consumirte mucho tiempo.
El único detalle que me gustaría marcar como negativo fue su menú principal. La navegación por el mismo me pareció incómoda y hasta me hizo creer en un principio que este juego no era compatible con mando. Con el resto de la interfaz (que tampoco es que haya demasiado más) no tuve problemas. Por ejemplo, la selección de elementos del inventario me resultó bastante cómoda y rápida.

[h1]Conclusión[/h1]
Una joya más del marco indie que vale la pena jugar. Una experiencia centrada en la narrativa y el terror psicológico, que considero que no puede faltar en tu biblioteca.

81625540.review:
Distraint is a linear psychological horror adventure game. You take control of Mr. Price as he battles his inner demons in a greedy world. Tasked with overseeing the removal of poor individuals from their homes for profit, Mr Price is haunted by the people whose lives he touches, and the ghosts of his disappointed parents. As his conscience weighs on him, his dark visions escalate.

The story itself is well written, but very depressing. It's not for everyone. The game puts a spotlight on disenfranchised people, and those who benefit from their suffering. Those with a sad mood might want to avoid this one. The game does offer a light at the end of the tunnel, but you see some bad stuff to get there.

The art direction is great. The Pixel graphics, the super wide aspect ratio, the small color pallets, and amazing post processing effects create something very harrowing and different. 

Sound design is on par with the graphics. The music is pretty subdued, mostly focusing on atmosphere rather than memorable themes. It sets the mood well.

The weakest aspect is probably the game play. I don't mind linear games, but some of the world and puzzle design felt off to me. I just got done playing "Little Miss Fortune" which has similar game play, but that game flowed better than this one. It didn't turn me off, but I think some would be unimpressed by it's simplicity and constant backtracking. Navigating can be a bit confusing as some areas look similar, and the way the 2D environments connect can feel abstract at times.

I quiet enjoyed this one and look forward to playing the sequel, which has been getting even stronger reviews. The fact this game was pretty much made by one person is incredible! They deserve a lot of praise!

with that out of the way, distraint ends up giving me some mad "christmas carol" vibes, with the themes it tackles. but this is no fun holiday romp -- this is a bloody, uniquely presented attack on what corporate life can do to your brain. there's a few weird plot moments, and i don't appreciate the point and click adventure logic, and it's BADLY in need of another proofread (one was credited??). overall, as a game and as a story though, it's pretty darn good, and with the sequel out now, it'll be easy to nab this one on the cheap.

79944393.review:
[b][h1]A brief description:[/h1][/b]
The story begins with Price visiting the home of the kind and elderly Mrs. Goodwin. Mrs. Goodwin has fallen behind on her payments, so Price, a young man who aspires for a partnership in a civil asset forfeiture group, has come to seize her home. Price bids farewell to a crying Mrs. Goodwin, and…well, let’s say this isn’t a [i]happy[/i] game. Price learns that greed comes at a cost. 

Distraint describes itself as a “2D psychological horror adventure game.” Distraint focuses on storytelling over horror elements (i.e. you won’t find any jump scares or zombies in this game), which allows it to build a rich horror atmosphere. Combined with an unusual art style and soundtrack, Distraint makes for a unique horror gaming experience. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2298252336

[b][h1]Why I [b]do[/b] recommend it:[/h1][/b]
Distraint is a genuinely exceptional gaming experience. This is one of those games I look at and question whether it leans more toward [i]game[/i] or [i]art[/i]. The visuals, soundtrack, story (and story pacing) come together nicely to create a great little two-hour artsy horror-gaming experience. Maybe that description is off-putting for some, but it’s the right blend of [i]awesome[/i] for this game.

Don’t be fooled by the short playtime. I was able to finish the game in about 2 hours, and it felt perfect at that length. Even at full price (the whole whopping $5.00) this game is worth the cost. But if you wait on a sale, you can pick it up for less than $1.00. This game is absolutely worth a dollar and two hours of your time!

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2298252393

[b][h1]The Good:[/h1][/b][list]
[*] Art and soundtrack gel amazingly
[*] Genuinely had me going “WTF!?!” a few times
[*] Super cheap. What’s not to like about a good cheap game?
[*] Easily playable with a controller, though it advertises as made for PC. I played through the game in one sitting on my couch using the Steam controller. Highly recommend playing the game this way!
[*] The game might seem short at only two hours long, but it’s perfect the way it is. I would have critiqued the length if it had gone longer.
[/list]

[b][h1]The Bad:[/h1][/b][list]
[*] I didn’t love one of the puzzles [spoiler]Mushroom puzzle speed run was a little not-fun and felt out of place with the rest of the game[/spoiler]
[*] I got stuck twice trying to figure out what the game wanted me to do, but I’m willing to chalk that up to me missing things I was able to interact with and not realizing I could interact with them (for example: there was a door on the right side of an area I didn’t know existed because of the angle of the doors when they’re on the sides of the maps – you see the thin section of the side of the door, not the front of the door, which made it difficult for me to realize it was there)
[/list]

79790450.review:
[h1]An almost unbearably bleak puzzler that doesn't reinvent the wheel, but it holds steady[/h1]
If you're ready to settle in for a particularly depressing adventure about the pressures of success, and the repercussions that come from pursuing a particularly cruel job and lifestyle, when all you really wanted yourself was a nice apartment - well, DISTRAINT is the game for you. It's not recommended for anyone who's already feeling depressed or sad, as it really is a tough game to stomach sometimes, with the atmosphere being depressing and rather cloying, meaning that your thoughts will dwell on the game and its events for some time afterwards. 

DISTRAINT is a 2D point and click adventure wherein you have to do your normal point and click stuff - go talk to people, interact with the environment, and solve puzzles. It's all done in a mostly fluid way, though I found a puzzle with mushrooms towards the end to be a particularly tough challenge of one's reflexes, when combined with a bit of pixel hunting to actually figure out where to go. But overall, the gameplay, while treading the well-worn path of countless adventure games that have come before it, is good. 

It's the story that adventure games are known for, and as mentioned before, DISTRAINT tells a bleak and oftentimes too-grim-to-stomach adventure. There are a few moments of levity, and some sweet or uplifting moments, but overall the tone of the game is dark and depressing. There's absolutely nothing wrong with this, and I genuinely enjoyed the story, but sometimes it all just got a bit too much. Perhaps it was what I was feeling when I played it a while back, but it really is a toughie, for all the good character writing and emotional moments it offers. I'll have to check out the sequel sometime, as I enjoyed this one enough to recommend it to others. 

It's not revolutionary, nor is it the most well-crafted adventure game you've ever played. But, if you're after a dark puzzler, this is the one for you.

77834598.review:
[h1]Joys of capitalism[/h1]

Distraint is a short little game about a guy who ruins people's lives by seizing their homes and leaving them with nothing.

The story is really nice and heartbreaking. There's not much anymore to tell regarding the story.
Gameplay is very simple. You walk around in a side-scrolling style of gameplay. You talk with people and solve puzzles while trying to not lose your mind.
Puzzles are quite simple but one particular section of the game was almost gamebreaking for me. The whole section where you're sniffing mushrooms is annoying and unnecessary confusing. I probably spent more time on that section than the rest of the game. Other than that everything was fine. Puzzles are not hard so they don't distract you from the characters and story for long and the whole game is very short.

Graphics are again as the game itself are very simplistic but I loved the animations and the whole graphics design from aesthetic point of view.

Sound design for the game of such small caliber is well done. There are no voice overs obviously, but overall sound design is great, creepy sounds and atmosphere makes this a good game for october.

This game is a little gem, I don't even remember where i've got it from and it was sitting my "crap" folder until I decided to sort games by horror tag to celebrate halloween month. I was pleasantly surprised. Worth playing if you love light horror, light puzzles and depressing stories.

[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
[*]Simple, short but good story
[*]Good graphical design
[*]Puzzles don't get in the way
[/list]
[b]Cons[/b]
[list]
[*]Mushroom section is frustrating
[/list]

Distraint es un juego corto (2 a 3 hrs)  en donde te narran la historia de  Price, el cual tiene el trabajo de desahuciar o embargar domicilios y esto lo hace para ganarse la vida, al principio hace esta acción sin importarle realmente que pasara con dicha gente en una vez que haya abandonado su casa , pero en el fondo le provoca remordimiento de culpa a Price, provocando  que  su subconsciente le cause  alucinaciones siniestras con el objetivo que se dé cuenta que su acciones están afectando la vida de  3° personas, ya que él hace hasta lo imposible para realizar su trabajo.

El terror que tiene el juego se presenta como alucinaciones, atmosfera  y uno que otro  sonido terrorífico predecible (pero el objetivo del juego en si no es asustarte sino más bien hacerte reflexionar), las mecánicas del juego son muy básicas y el juego tiene puzles realmente fáciles de realizar, por lo cual todo el peso del juego se va a la narrativa (la cual parece una fábula).

El juego tiende a infundirte algunas preguntas en el transcurso de la historia como: 

 ¿Qué  estarías dispuesto hacer para cumplir tus sueños y metas? 

¿Y si tuvieras que afectar a 3° personas para cumplir tus objetivos los harías?

En pocas palabras si vale la pena el juego (más si esta en rebajas) siempre y cuando tengas el tiempo para ser consciente de la narrativa que te plantean.
