75652137.review:
[h1] Un esclavo de tus propias decisiones [/h1]

En esta primera entrega nos encontramos con un Protagonista vendido al capitalismo y a su propia avaricia a manos de la empresa McDade, Bruton & Moore, cuyo trabajo se basa en embargar a gente humilde. En pleno ascenso al éxito profesional e infierno ético, Distraint abarca sentimientos implícitos de miedo, odio, avaricia, culpa, pena...todos ellos entremezclados con experiencias pasadas y presentes de Price, quien en esta fabula moral, se va viendo sumido en una desgracia que se separa de lo vanal y estético. Las constantes renuncias del videojuego a dejarte a solas te distancian tanto a ti como a Price de momentos a solas en los que reflexionar y dedicarte a ti mismo, lo que lo hace más real y verosímil, pues los problemas que van surgiendo de tus acciones se sobreponen, y van creando una pila colosal de mierda, cimentada por una base fúnebre y oscura que se deja entrever muy inusualmente. Este continuo vaivén de emociones termina con un factor que te deja en vilo ante un precipicio del cual no conoces la caída pero, por el que desciendes igualemente porque no encuentras un propósito por el que seguir moviéndote. 

[spoiler] Y por ello, acaba con una secuencia final en que Price introduce una escopeta en su boca y al disparar nos entregan un fundido en negro, que nos atrapa en un desconocimiento del final de Price, que aunque se hace evidente resulta intrigante. [/spoiler]

Por último, expresar mi gratitud a Jesse Makkonen, por entregarnos una joya de este cáliz que tanto me ha hecho pensar y reflexionar acerca de la condición humana y sus aplicaciones en las controversias de la vida.

74361006.review:
4/10

If you liked The Cat Lady or Downfall, then don't buy this game. It tries to do what they did with the dark mood and bloody visuals, but it doesn't hold a candle to The Cat Lady. The puzzles don't hold much meaning, and some of them are downright irritating. It forces you along paths that are needlessly long, which might have been acceptable if the plot had been at least interesting.

And oh, the plot! The overarching storyline is unique enough, but that's about it. Nothing has been done to make it even remotely interesting, and the game tries to hide this fact through jumpscares and grotesque imagery. Oh, you're curious how the main character even got this job of expropriating property? Well too bad! Turn your attention to that vaguely disturbing object that just materialized out of nowhere! Why is that relevant? Well, that's just some clever symbolism representing the character's inner thoughts and.....yeah, no.

You could summarize the game into something that lasts half an hour, and it wouldn't make much of a difference. But that would've made it last under the two hour mark, giving cause to a bunch of refunds! Then stretch it out with some needless puzzles! That's the answer! Well, newsflash: more is not necessarily better. In this case, it's worse.

73466216.review:
Pequeño juego que pertenece al género de aventura gráfica en la que debes resolver una serie de puzzles muy sencillos para avanzar en la trama. Eres Price y trabajas en una multinacional con muchas propiedades y muchos inquilinos, algunos de los cuales pasan apuros para pagar lo que deben, y tu tarea es informar a aquellas personas que no han cumplido su pago que deben abandonar su casa, eres un desahuciador. 
Price tiene conciencia de lo que hace y no le gusta pero quiere una vida mejor y al final no le importa el daño que provoca con su curro; hasta que conoce a la señora Goodwin y su vida cambia y nosotros veremos ese proceso mientras se sume en una depresión que le lleva a tener pesadillas y alucinaciones que dan al juego un toquecillo de terror que hasta te hará brincar de la silla con sus 4 jumpscares.
Juego en el que destaca sobre todo que lo hizo un solo tío, Jesse Makkonen, y le ha quedado muy chulo y bastante decente sin llegar a ser gran cosa. 
Tiene cositas malas pero no especialmente graves. Quizá lo peor sea que todo el juego consiste en hacer siempre lo mismo, andar por ahí buscando cosas que usar en determinados lugares para seguir avanzando, y al final es algo que cansa un poco y eso que es corto. Solo hay un puzzle que es distinto pero es tan fácil que se desaprovecha. Tampoco es algo que critique mucho porque yo creo que el creador buscaba más contar una historia que desafiarte para avanzar, tanto es así que ni puedes morir en todo el juego, y eso está bien pero un mayor componente jugable hubiera estado mejor. Tampoco ayuda que dichos puzzles, en su mayoría, no tengan lógica alguna de modo que la gente que vas a echar de su casa te piden antes de firmar un favor que no cabe en lógica alguna. Quizá sea fruto de la mente cada vez más tocada de Price pero creo que no es así porque para eso salen esas partes perturbadoras para reflejar eso. Y tampoco esto es algo grave pero a mí me sacó del juego un poquito porque cuenta una historia bastante realista con subtramas sin sentido.
Todo lo demás muy bien, tanto la música como su aspecto visual (que es feo pero chulo a la vez) están conseguidos de forma adecuada, los diálogos son buenos y la historia también, acabando en un final que a mí me gustó bastante.
Juego recomendable aunque al ser del tipo que es, a muchos ni les interesará probarlo. Es muy barato así que el precio no es excusa. Buen trabajo de Jesse Makkonen y ya tengo ganas de jugar a la secuela.

Nota: 7

72922118.review:
[code]Curator page here-->[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/37670120/] DaRevieweD #32 [/url]<-- [i]New review every Sunday[/i][/code]

Distraint is made by lone indie developer, Jesse Makkonen from Finland. Now I know I've become a sucker for solo devs as of late~ But apparently I had even owned his first game "Silence of The Sleep" without knowing it, so that's pretty cool and I'll get to it one of these days! 

Then it hit me, they must have a hard time with promotions. Since I only saw this game from the hot deals Steam was having and was surprised why I had never seen (or rather paid attention to) it before! Reading the synopsis- I immediately thought of "Drag Me to Hell" and that cemented my decision to an already irresistible bundle of OG Distraint, an improved deluxe version and its sequel!! Alas, how will this turn out?


[h1]"Paid My Dues"[/h1]

[u]The Gist:[/u]
Price is a debt collector who isn't doing the best financially. So, in an attempt to not pass up a rags-to-riches offer of making partner with McDade, Burton and Moore- he agrees to some legally but not morally justified decisions by evicting three individuals. However, he may not be as resilient as he thought because his actions begin to torment him slowly at first.... but surely. Can he go through with it after all? 

[spoiler] ! Last notice. You've been warned. [/spoiler]


[h1][+] PROS;[/h1]

[b](a) The Descent[/b]
Gameplay consists of 2D exploration and puzzle-solving, nothing too complex usually for a key item to unlock the next area or meet up with someone. Pick up an item, store it and then use it on another point of interest. If it sounds extremely simple, that's because it is which is a good thing! There is not even a button to run! Therefore, the controls are easy to master and don't distract you from being immersed in the well-crafted story, disturbing experiences as well as hopefully being able to take away the central lesson. 

Initially the game my seem cut-and-dry as it starts you off right away in the first distraint scenario and then plagued by the guilt shortly after. Then you return to your dwellings to start the next case. But you'll be surprised to hear it has a reasonable pace!

[b](b) A Deadly Sin[/b] 
I thought the plot was the strongest part of the game. Price is not actually a bad person, not at all instead he's just doing his job or so he tries to tell himself. Seeing him bothered by how the eviction affected the three very different individuals showed his treatment of others is still very humane. This is also apparent in how he tries to make the process as smooth and considerate as possible by fulfilling their requests. Some took more of a toll on him than others, particularly the elderly woman in poor health.

[spoiler]She could also technically be considered as the main "antagonist" because she's the source of his nightmares.[/spoiler] However, that would be presumptuous of me because after all Price brought it on himself and he has been shown to be rather materialistic as well by opting to get things like a new coffee maker and fantasizing of a better place, as is the aim of life after all.

[b](c) Shred of Sanity[/b] 
The game has a dark sense of humor and you often question whether it's appropriate to burst out laughing but then you do it anyways. There are many instances where you can "pretend" to match an obviously wrong item during your interactions which will actually hint at Price's defining trait- the ability to crack a joke and laugh at himself, the situation or both! These also nab you achievements and are just some harmless fun~ 

There also some rarer 4th wall-breaking dialogue such as when you save your progress which only make you realize this is a game based on reality. Then it sets in- how the game makes you take delight in every moment. Price's bosses encouraging him to do a celebratory dance is a small sign of control and priming him to take pleasure in the work.    

[b](d) Looking Out for No. 1[/b] 
I've probably touched on some of the horror elements; its close to home topic of debt, greed and what it can unleash. Now we'll explore more on what makes this scary. 

1st) The graphics- the grainy filter and design of the characters make them out to look barely human. This suits the central idea of Price selling himself for a chance at the grand life. For example, whether the grotesque and gory happenings that occur are real or has Price gone mad beyond saving? These hallucinations, nightmares although unnerving on their own; the often unknown sounds and excessively off-putting visuals. All these can be [spoiler]said to be symptoms of a mental illness playing out in extreme forms.[/spoiler] 

2nd) One section where he dabbles in an unknown substance to overcome obstacles as part of a puzzle subtly alluding to drugs of which is another indulgence he may well end up doing to ease his pain.

3rd) [Spoiler] There's also the fact that regardless of how badly you want to have a say in Price's choices and affect the outcome, you'll find it's impossible and you have to bear witness to what unfolds[/spoiler]. Case in point, the ending which is a real downer and I'd be lying if I said it didn't make me self-reflect.


[h1][-] CONS;[/h1]

[b](i) Not of Sound Mind[/b] 
I did encounter one interaction issue where the prompt to interact appears but is untouchable as if no description was written to begin with. However, perhaps most irritating is the slight delay or inconsistent near unpredictable nature of the prompt appearing when trying to examine stuff/people. When moving, the prompt doesn't appear- that's fine. So just stop right?

 But then you can only interact with them when facing at the right direction (often only one fixed one). It gets worse during one timed sequences! Of course, there's also how sometimes you can interact from an arm length's away and then others breathing down their necks. 

[b](ii) You'll Live[/b]
I mentioned that the puzzles are straightforward but they required quite a bit of backtracking, I'm sorry "backwalking" for such a linear game. I also had times where I went "huh" at the logic of some puzzles. I get that the world, his mental state become questionable and so this is mirrored in the puzzles. Still weird though... 

The scares also rely more on shock value and may have been a tad too violent, dare I say to the point of player desensitization. Unless, that was the point... There was one other baffling encounter where the same jumpscares were done twice in exactly the same way and it really bugged me.


[h1]"But Not The Price?"[/h1]

To conclude, Distraint is an exceptional 2D horror adventure that easily stands out with its scarring premise and very realistic portrayal of how greed can lead to one's spiral of regret. It poses a genuine dilemma that's still relevant- whether a person is ever truly sure of the difference between want and need. The despicable decisions that Price (or rather you) resorts to and the horrid episodes to punish you remain the most iconic scenes. 

Though that does reputation fall short at times by certain vexing interactions and cheap scares. This short game is arguably worth the $5 tag and though you have the power to quit at any moment, you will find that desire robbed as it forces you to continue. The worst part is- you just might enjoy it.   


[h1]8.5/10[/h1]

[b]Apparently there's a direct sequel so we'll see how that goes~[/b]

[h1]Really makes you wonder[/h1]

This is a little gem often walked past upon by people. Maybe because of the pixel graphics (I am not a fan myself either, but if a game has a great story or gameplay, i don't care), or maybe because of the tag 'Psychological Horror' (which, confused me first time i saw it)., psychological horror doesn't mean "boo! be spooked" i have learned few years back, but it refers to the fact that it can create a mental discomfort, in this case, because of an saddening story and the drama that comes with it.

It plays with your emotions quite a bit, and makes you walk into the shoes of the characters.

I consider it a really good game that touched some spots of my feelings that other games didn't quite hit, and if you like games with deep thoughts and powerful messages, this is for you.

I have yet to play the sequel, but i think i will love it just like i did with the first.

70645263.review:
I learned a new word today.   

Apparently it means seizing somebody's property as payment for money owed, which makes sense since that's what you'll be doing.  Basically you're like a repo man who goes around evicting people from their homes and it ends up serving as the basis for a sort of morality play.

I wish I could think of something highbrow and capital-L Literary to compare this to so my high school English teachers would be proud.  I mean, there's got to be a story like this out there somewhere, right?  What keeps coming to mind, though, is that movie where Keanu Reeves gets a job at Satan's law firm.  Whereas that one dealt with pride up in the skyscrapers of New York, here you're down in the muck with good old money-grubbing greed.

What profit a man if he gain a coffee maker but lose his soul?

In matters of conscience like this, the tension is always in the tug of war between the angel and the devil on your shoulders.  We hear an awful lot from the devil's end.  The author clearly relishes this Grand Guignol style and takes every opportunity to indulge in all its lurid excesses.  

Scenes light up like stage acts in glaring oversaturated spotlights.  Daring brush strokes of color, shadow and sound imbue the drama with a demented vitality.   Blood-splattered, carnivalesque visions of the surreal haunt the protagonist like Furies; and it's all played out by bobbleheaded little caricatures that give it the feel of a macabre puppet show.  Very striking.

Problem is, the angel side of the battle doesn't get the same airtime.  A single concrete thread of nagging guilt runs throughout; but somber and touching as it is, it fails to counterbalance the manic energy of the game's dark side.  They're having so much fun that you get the sense they pull their punch a little, and it ends up weakening the impact of the whole parable.

They refer, for example, to the protagonist's family from time to time, yet this aspect of his character is never really developed in full.  It could have added some extra depth to his motivations and real emotional weight to the decisions he makes.  The story does manage to create some pathos, and even ends with a neatly tied-off loop; but it falls short of the real tragedy that it might have reached with a little more thorough attention to detail.  

For all its virtues, then, this game never quite manages to exceed the sum of its parts; but fortunately the parts themselves are all pretty good so you still wind up ahead.  Just not as far as you might have liked.



You can find more indie game reviews at [url=https://oddlittlegames.com] oddlittlegames.com [/url] or visit my [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/34514756/] curator page. [/url]  Thanks, and enjoy!

For all the work and effort that clearly went into this game, a sense of strain shows, You see, Distraint can be pretty interesting and keeps you rolling forward. It's creator had a good sense of what they wanted to do with this, poured their hearts out. It could be considered almost a 2D Silent Hill at times, other times its a streamlined click and point horror, a modern evolution of games like Dark Seed and the such. BUT near in its final moments you can sense that things were getting tight and it just needed to be finished.

If its a story of integrity, greed, choices, or just meant to shock without any real tangible plan - I can't really tell. So much happens, but the implications or what it implies is going on it scant or not there. This makes its ending rather... less shocking then it should have been. Less shocking and less clever.

Still it is  a great effort put out by one person, interesting to play - I only wish maybe they had gotten some help with or worked through a few more drafts of the story.

Distraint is a good game.
Puzzles are challenging, but not ridiculous (except for those damn mushrooms), and the story is intriguing and beautifully animated.
Here we follow the journey (or perhaps downfalls would be more correct) of a Mr. Price.
The game is a mild psychological horror story, which can be completed with 100% achievements in under three hours (excellent guides exist).

My only qualm was the ending, which I found significantly too depressing.
BUT, if you play Distraint 2 (which I highly recommend you do), it will alleviate the issue I had with the ending, and takes the story in a different, more positive direction.

And the word 'distraint' actually means - "the seizure of someone's property in order to obtain payment of money owed, especially rent." This is quite a hint for what the game is about (don't worry, that's not a spoiler!)

68281259.review:
Me gustó el juego, aunque no considero que sea para caulquier público; considero que va más enfocado a las personas que les gusta reflexionar sobre temas existenciales, temas mentales, etc... No digo que las demás personas no lo puedan disfrutar de igual manera, si no que es más probable que sea más valorado (en buena o mala manera) por las personas que previamente mencioné.

El juego es de terror psicológico? Estrictamente hablando sí, porque el personaje es el que sufre por sus emociones. Sin embargo, yo prefiero los juegos que perturban o hacen reflexionar a uno como jugador/espectador; algo así como el bad ending de alguna novela visual o bien como una "creepypastas" de las buenas (o como la primera vez que leíste una sin saber si quiera que era una creepypasta). Distraint no logra eso; no al menos conmigo; y estoy seguro que con muchas personas tampoco.

Me gusta como un todo: en este momento pensaba criticar el final, pero me retracto; es un final que es interesante y se le puede interpretar dos ó tres cosas a través de la forma en que uno mire la vida.

En cuanto a los puzzles, la verdad son muy sencillos de resolver; tampoco es un paseo, pero tampoco es que sea como un templo del agua de ocarina of time en dificultad (o algo extremadamente críptico o difícil de resolver). Pero eso sí, son interesantes.

Es un juego económico, y de por sí muy barato cuando está de oferta. La pregunta es, deberías darle una oportunidad? A mi criterio sí, sobre todo si disfrutas de preguntarte cosas existenciales de la vida.

Como punto extra, se encuentra en español.

68243021.review:
Wonderful short adventure game. 

Distraint is narrative game, focused on creating a disturbing horror vibe to accompany it's fable-like tale. 
While the game does have adventure-game like puzzles, I would recommend this for people who value unique and interesting short stories. 
I've never played a story like this before in games and think this game tackles it well. It creates the perfect atmosphere to accompany it, with quirky visuals that distort and change, and splattered with weird, gross stuff out of the blue, and weird ambient music.

The game does have puzzles, mostly "find the item and use it on stuff" you expect from these kind of games. Most are quite easy to work out which is good, I would say tough roadblocks would bring the game down. There is ONE of these and it is probably the only bad part of the game (it's a timed puzzle, where you have to slowly backtrack each time to restart it) but most are fun and make you feel involved in the game.

Indie fans, story games fans and quirky game fans will love this one.

67133596.review:
After playing Heal, I circled back to Distraint. It has been a lovely game (art, music, story) until a sequence of two timed puzzles with running and getting through doors (you have just over 6 seconds). I finally got through the first part but missed the second destination so I need to restart the entire sequence yet again.  The save system has been great but is not available at the 'mid point' of this sequence.

This is a deal breaker for me. I'd love to play the rest of the game to see how the story turns out, but I have moved from fun to frustration. I've spent about 1/3 of my time in the game trying, without success, to get past this set of scenes.

As mentioned, this is a wonderful adventure and I'd recommend it to gamers who can move fast and decisively and have a high tolerance for timed runs.  Those who are not quite as quick on the keys might want to look elsewhere.

Added Note: I just could not walk away from this game so persevered through the rough spot. It was well worth getting to play through to the ending which is powerful and thought provoking! I'm glad I did not quit...

64016052.review:
[h1]Pointless[/h1]

"Distraint: Deluxe Edition" is not a bad game and, for 4E, you can probably think of carrying it out for a spin, but it's not memorable and won't blow your mind.

The game is a very simple graphic adventure: it's simpler than a "point and click" game, in the sense that you don't need to even point: everything happens on in 1D - you move left and right essentially - and interact at specific points where an object or character is located.

This stripped to the bone adventure system is not bad actually, and makes the game relaxing and enjoyable despite the content.

The graphics are peculiar and the sound compartment is very very good: fx especially are AAA in my opinion.

The game reminds more than a bit "Lone Survivor" (do get it if you don't know what I mean) and seems to be at the forefront of the current Indie trend of low tech, low production value games with great gameplay and story, but...

The story and the puzzles are unfortunately Distraint's Achille's heel: the script clicks - at least at the start - but it becomes more confused and pointless as the story progresses.

The puzzles are completely arbitrary and make no sense (sure you are in the head of a man with a mental disorder but... if this is the bar for "making sense", you probably have no bar) so you ping pong from one location to the other combining objects and waiting for the next "Deus ex machina" to happen.

I'm not panning the game but, frankly, even if it's cheap (and I got it even cheaper than this) it wasn't worth my time.

2.2/5

63571551.review:
[h1]Pros:[/h1]
[list]
[*]El gameplay es sencillo. Sólo puedes moverte a los lados e interactuar. Y tienes un inventario con tres ranuras para recoger y usar objetos. Los objetos tienes que buscarlos por cada nivel y llevarlos de un lado a otro, resolviendo algún que otro puzle por el camino. No son ningún reto, son sólo para mantenerte activo. El juego en sí mismo es lineal, corto y totalmente narrativo.

[*]La historia es dramática pero bastante simple. No tiene nada que destaque demasiado.

[*]Muy atmosférico. El sonido y la estética están ayudan mucho en eso. Y aunque el juego tiene un estilo de arte simple y pixelado, los colores y la iluminación están bastante logrados.
[/list]

[h1]Contras:[/h1]
[list]
[*]Hay un nivel con un puzle en el que tienes que desbloquar puertas e ir corriendo hasta ellas antes de que se acabe el tiempo y se vuelvan a bloquear. Es la única parte del juego que se pueda decir que es mala. Es confusa y frustrante, sobretodo porque el nivel es un poco laberíntico. No demasiado, pero algunas partes tienes que explorarlas mientras corres, sin estar seguro de a dónde te tienes que dirigir, y reiniciar el recorrido sin no llegas a donde debías.

[*]El juego cae un poco en ese problema que tienen las aventuras gráficas de tener que probar aleatoriamente los objetos que tengas en diferentes sitios cuando te quedas atascado, a ver si así avanzas. No ocurre demasiado ni es muy grave, porque los niveles son demasiado simples como para que tengas que pierdas demasiado tiempo en ello. Pero sigue siendo un poco cutre.

[*]Algunos de los detalles siniestros que se ven durante el juego no se sabe qué intentan representar exactamente.

61958913.review:
"Going cheap like always... the story of my life."

This is literally the story of this game..
It's a bit too short to call it a full game and it doesn't really have anything great enough you would want to remember after you finish it either... so I can't really recommend it to anyone.
Story is interesting enough in the beginning to pull you in and make you play it but through till the end it just feels empty and forced. I felt like I had to do a few things to progress further on and before I knew it the game was over and there is no replay value; but seriously, for $4 and under a dollar on sale, what would you expect of a game...

Characters have no depth, there's no backstory to any, only necessary interaction; the game itself feels not a lot of fun to play all the way through; the save feature is nice but not really, it doesn't go that well with the look of the game, it makes it look more of a miniclip rather than a full game and it's tedious and not necessary unless you want to take a break... The graphics are not a thrill, pixel graphics is not my favourite but at least the color palette was on-point. There are no graphics settings tho. There isn't a lot to say about the gameplay, going back and forth for 2 hours with 2 buttons use and inventory... not diverse and not thrilling at all..

The verdict of this game is bland and short.

61886018.review:
What to say about it beside it’s one of those wicked indie games with the “end message”. It’s a psychological thriller adventure with occasional jumpscares, although not intensive, which add to the complete atmosphere of the game. The narative is nice and keeps pushing you towards the end game. Graphics are artistic and nice, and perfectly fit the overall game experience. Speaking of gameplay, it relies on basic controls and is easy to play. There are also few easy puzzles here and there.
Regarding playtime it’s a short game. I’ve finished it in two hours. It could be finished sooner.
Nevertheless it’s long enough to tell the story.

If you like short indie games, then I recommend you to play it.

I really must emphasize that, in my opinion, it’s not suitable for the people suffering from anxiety and depression.

**Personal score: 7/10**

61724219.review: Distraint is a game that tells a story about how greed destroys the soul of its main character, Price. It is a short yet terrifying look at how the guilt and emotions a person may feel from hurting others for their own gain cannot be erased or suppressed. No matter the lip service a person might give to others to compensate for taking advantage of them, the guilt of their conscience will chase them down and kill them. As the scenarios in Distraint show, those most likely to be abused are poor, elderly, or vulnerable in some way. Ultimately, "what goes around comes around." A nice little story with a lesson on morality, set in uniquely terrifying environments.

61429083.review:
[h1]Something really beautiful[/h1]

Distraint is a game in which we play the role of Price, a young man who works for a company and his job is to occupy people's homes. After occupying the apartment of an old woman, our hero starts having nightmares, but to find out how his story will end, you have to experience the story of this game yourself.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

It's a point&click adventure game where all we need to play is a keyboard. We won't find an open world here, and the storyline is linear, but we have a great atmosphere.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]

The graphics are simple, pixel-like, and 2D.  Although the whole game is shown "from the side", the elements of the world look beautiful. The most attention is paid to the game with colors. When something bad happens, the colors on the screen immediately inform us about it.

[h1]Sound[/h1]

Music is another great part of this game. The sound effects are very good. The game is wraped up as a horror movie and you can really hear it. The music is dark and introduces an amazing atmosphere.

[h1]Summary[/h1]

Distraint is a really good game, with nice simple graphics and charming soundtrack. The atmosphere of the game is on a high level. It's hard to get attached to something, but for a game created by one man, the game is worth every price and costs little to fix.
[b]
✔️Game climate
✔️Simple graphics, attention to detail
✔️Very good and dark soundtrack
✔️Great, shocking ending

✔️❌Simple puzzles

❌Our character is too slow
❌Linear storyline


[i]Time of completion:  5-6 hours[/i]

[b][u]Rating: 7/10[/u][/b]

59917947.review:
Distraint was a pleasant surprise to me. It is a very meaningful story with important message told in a clever way. At first, you might not realize how deep and grim the story actually is but slowly as you progress you will start to understand the hidden meaning behind it.

Is your humanity worth selling for riches and career ? Will it make you happy if you forsake your humanity for those ? Or is it a ticket to hell ? That is what our character Price (very ironic name indeed) slowly discovers a hard way.

The game is very short (around 3 hours) and the gameplay is very simplistic but I finished it in one session and was immersed for a whole time. 

There are few puzzles to solve and some interactable objects needed for that but other than that, it's 2D adventure that is story driven without many gameplay options. Not that it is a bad thing, it certainly isn't in this case.

The soundtrack is fitting and few tracks are very nice, especially towards the end.

Highly recommended game. Those 3 hours were well spent indeed.

59788440.review:
For the first half of this game it is OK, it makes enough sense to warrant playing it and you are waiting for the horror to start.

Then from the third act onwards it just goes to pot - quite literally - and starts to make no sense and forces you to repeat things over and over again and the horror never starts.

An altered state of mind mechanic is bought into play where you can only access doorways and items while out of your head - for very short frustrating periods of time – while adding in a very exasperating maze puzzle.

Cue youtube video search where I watched a streamer do exactly the same as I was doing and getting nowhere.

They eventually got past the things I couldn’t but I still needed it again for the last level.

Which is unacceptable because most of the ‘puzzles’ were illogical and come down to simply trudging around using an object on everything you can until it works.

In summary – exasperating, illogical, frustrating, repetitive and tortuous.

I did stick it out to the end, but having completed it it certainly isn’t another To The Moon.

I also have the second one but am not sure I will ever be compelled to play it after this.

58234918.review:
[h3][i][b]How much is your moral compass worth?[/b][/i][/h3] 
Pierce is a hard-working young man, looking to get his partnership with the McDade, Bruton & Moore firm, and with it, a nice paycheck. This seems like a normal thing to aspire for, and yet sometimes, we flush our moral compass down the drain in order to achieve financial happiness. What happens to a person once he sees the consequences of his actions and how they affect others? How does one cope with making others suffer due to his personal aspirations? This is where [i][b]Distraint[/b][/i] shines, weaving emotional trauma and psychological-horror together, creating an uneasy atmosphere and telling a cautionary tale of how blind ambition can easily turn into greed when we forgo our moral compass. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2261627035

[h3][i][b]You can walk to the left, but you can also walk to the right[/b][/i][/h3] 
It’s similar to the Telltale formula - walk and explore the area, do some puzzles, with quite a bit of backtracking, so you can progress to a new level. I wish there was more to say about the gameplay, but sadly it’s a very basic 2D side scroller with simple puzzles. This is fine, as the game puts a heavy emphasis on its story.  
 
[h3][i][b]Pixel graphics doesn’t mean less detail[/b][/i][/h3] 
Even with its “simple” pixel art style, the world you explore is rich in detail with each location being handcrafted and unique. The uneasy images you encounter throughout your journey create a decent horror atmosphere, and the astounding ambient music does wonders, making it even better. Music is often a big part of evoking emotion from the players, and Jesse has done a great job with the soundtrack, delivering some hard gut punches. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2261728278
 
[h3][b][i]Final Thoughts[/i][/b][/h3] 
If you enjoy story-driven games that evoke strong emotions and convey a powerful message, this is a [b]must buy[/b]. While it does not offer complex gameplay or challenging puzzles, with its amazing atmosphere, accompanied by the mesmerizing soundtrack, the players' focus will be on the real star of the show –[b] the story[/b]. The future is very bright for Jesse, and I can't wait to play his next game.

57838788.review:
[h1]What Comes Around, Goes Around[/h1]

Distraint is a bit-sized 2D psychological-horror game from Finnish developer Jesse Makkonen now re-released with new color palette, enhanced animation and lighting. The story is about an ambitious young man named Price who happens to be just an ordinary guy working for a greedy company that seizes people’s property. In exchange for a partnership with his employers Price is sent to meet with three people who he must inform can no longer stay in their home. 

Price is portrayed as a genuinely good guy who just wants to live a normal life. He isn't chasing after exorbitant riches; All he wants is a home that doesn't leak in rainy days but at what cost? As the story progresses he can feel that his humanity is gone, so the rest of his journey follows him dealing with himself and his choices along the way. His basic desires, rather than a hyperbolic chasing of wealth, shift the game to a neutral perspective that allow you to sympathize with both Price and the victims of his line of work. In conclusion the story is about "regrets".

The gameplay is kept simplistic but very effective and that works. Most of the time you would find items and solve simple puzzles. Creative mix of artistic design, sound with pixelated horror effects makes Distraint a very unique experience. The soundtrack is yet again very beautiful and just feels natural given the game's tone and the stuff you see in the game! I gotta appreciate that the entire game was crafted by one guy and that's pretty impressive and puts other games from similar genre to shame. Distraint's story is twisted but the developer also delivers positive [and negative] messages but how you take it is left upto you.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
-Skillfully told story that's very engaging and touching
-Good use of dark humor 
-Soundtrack that just works really well...
-Perfect balance of creepy atmosphere and some refreshing moments that'll keep you engaged with the 2 hour adventure
-Compelling premise of self-destructive regrets
-satisfying ending (wished if there were multiple endings)

[h1]Cons[/h1]
-No interactive dialogues 
-Some grammer mistakes due to poor translation
-No way to rebind keys or change graphical settings
-A bit too short

[h1] My Rating: 8/10 [/h1]

I bought it on sale and it was worth every penny. The duration of the game and the sale price of the game kinda balance themselves out in that aspect I suppose. It's on sale frequent number of times, so yes I recommend; do buy it. Distraint is a damn fine horror game which will keep you hooked with Price's adventures.

57177757.review:
Price's job, as a distrainor, is to seize people's property to make sure he can obtain payment of rent which has long been owed. He doesn't like his job regardless of how famous the company is he works for but this is something he needs to make do with. The game starts out by introducing Price's first distraint; property to be seized from an elderly woman.

Price becomes tormented by this case and this gets progressively worse along the way following his subsequent clients. We can see his story through in a couple of hours and the store page provides an excellent summary when saying he'll "learn the price of his humanity".

I read a couple of reviews for this game and decided this would be an instant purchase as I thought this would provide the same experience as another horror adventure had done before: "Home". Don't let the simplistic, pixelated 2D graphics deter you from playing this game: it has great atmosphere and an excellent moral at the end. It should also be noted that this was the produce of a single individual.

If you like psychological horror adventures with twists and you don't mind that they can only satisfy your hunger for the terrifying for a couple of hours (due to their low-budget, indie nature) then do yourself a favour and give Distraint a chance.

56298651.review:
I went into this without many expectations, but I ended up highly impressed.

Its an indie psychological thriller game with horror elements that has been executed in a very professional manner.

The Good:
1. Well thought out and paced story with interesting turns and strong messages.
2. Beautiful aesthetics (arguably).
3. Wonderful atmosphere (aided by the music).
4. Puzzles that aren't hard enough as to take you out of the atmosphere, but aren't necessarily no brainers.
5. Doesn't overstay its welcome (lasts about has long as a game like this should).
6. Great for the price.

The "Improvable":
1. The mechanics of the drug-based level doesn't fit with the feeling of the rest of the game at all.

Quite genuinely that was my only complaint. 

To summarise, if you are looking for a game in this genre, you won't be disappointed by what this game has to offer.

Overall: 8.5/10

This game was... discomforting. I was engrossed in it for a good 2 hours, made so by the the depressing narrative, frightening visuals and atmospheric music. There was many a moment where I had to stop to allow myself to process what I just saw.
Great story done with very little. Seeing Price torn between what his morals tell him and his vision of success was hard to witness. 

The soundtrack is a little bit in your face, but it pays off. This game isn't quite scary, though it seems that way at times. It is more disturbing and odd with a dash of humor. "We have yet to see you DANCE, son!"

Hard to believe this was all done by one guy, but at the same time the game feels like it was so. In any case, this is an impressive game well worth the asking price. I usually rate when I leave reviews but I feel like that would be doing this game a disservice. I'll do it anyway. Great/10.

Cuando me regalaron este juego no me llamó demasiado la atención. Hasta que le dí una oportunidad y lo probé. ¿Cómo lo describiría? Es un juego bastante paranoico. Sobretodo al comienzo. Es muy bizarro y contiene escenas muy crueles, en las que ya no sabes si lo que estás viendo es real, o es locura del personaje. Tiene una historia muy atractiva, tanto que me pasé el juego en una partida. Además tiene una trama muy elaborada, en la que se vé lo peor (y lo mejor) de las personas. Cómo el dinero y el poder pueden contra toda moral.

Una de las cosas que más me gustaron del juego es que al principio ves mucha sangre y cosas aparentemente aleatorias, pero que luego van cobrando sentido al final del juego. Dando como resultado una historia interminable de la que aún no estoy convencido de si me dejó con buen sabor de boca. 

En definitiva: ¿Por el precio que vale? Te diría que sí que merece la pena darle una oportunidad. Y si te lo regalan como a mí o similar, No tienes ninguna excusa para no jugarlo. Es como ver una película, con una fantástica banda sonora y efectos de terror paranoide. Simplemente, me encantó. Y es de los mejores en su categoría.

[h1]DISTRAINT: Moral Ambiguity and Avarice[/h1]

[b]DISTRAINT[/b] is a thoroughly enjoyable game; it is an eerie, sometimes uncomfortable but meaningful experience. The aesthetics complement the narrative and themes in tone, with even the juxtaposition of the gore and cuteness acting as a visual parallel to the story-line. It has elements from a number of genres but I’d especially recommend it to fans of horror point-and-click games.

cliche cautionary tale told creatively. you play as a guy at a law firm, whose job is to expropriate properties from their inhabitants. you run around and talk to three clients to get them to sign their papers; (a nice old lady who cant afford rent; some guy whose cabin collides with the building of a highway, and some mushroom eating druggie.)

gameplay is basically you pick up things along the way and use it on other interactable objects. tbh this game would be really frustrating to play without following a walkthrough guide. but if u dont mind adventure games like leisure suit larry or ceville where u need to follow a guide to progress because some solutions are outright left field, (like randomly guzzling an entire water dispenser to serve as distraction that i didnt know i needed), then the story is worth going thru.

-immersive sound design

cons:
-frustrating gameplay

55130709.review: Distraint is a side-scrolling adventure game with simplistic puzzle elements. The main draw of the game is the grim story and art style. The plot focuses on a young man who is questioning the morals of his work and this narrative thread proceeds to unfold in a rather interesting manner. The art and sound design mix together to create a bleak atmosphere and the unique way in which the game is presented visually makes it stand out from other titles. The gameplay, while enjoyable, is pretty simple. Most puzzles involve making sure you check every interactable object and room, which there are typically only a handful of. Once finding the objects you need and experimenting a tiny bit the answers are pretty straight forward. While the puzzles are simplistic and generally fine, the plot and art are what really make the game engaging.

54537043.review:
What job could possibly be worse than an Arstotzkan border control agent? How about being Mr. Price and having to go evict people from their homes for various reasons, and doing it all so you can secure your own door with a fancy nameplate bearing your name. It's all about hitting the big leagues, and even your dead parents can't convince you that what you are doing is inhuman and wrong. Like most whippersnappers, you just have to learn the hard way.

Distraint takes you through the budding career of Mr. Price, as he travels from home to home, telling people it is time for them to pack up their crap and hit the road. The fact that this came from one person in a very short amount of time is actually pretty impressive. While it may not be the next Layers of Fear, it was enjoyable in its own right. It is not a very long game, and that is a huge plus for this genre. Games like Layers of Fear are great, but they drag of for so long that you get bored halfway through the game and just cannot wait for the "pain" to end. You do not have this issue with Distraint. On sale or full price, totally worth it.

54474857.review:
/r/im14andthisisdeep material unfortunately. It all seemed rather juvenile, literally pasting the word "GREED!!!!!!!!" all over the walls and such. And I'm not sure the creator understands the nature of employment. They do realize that if Price quit his job someone else would just fill his position and the injustice would just continue, right? Or that him doing what he ultimately decides upon in the end might afford him the ability to change the unforgiving nature of the company?

I was very disappointed with how little the horror elements actually accomplished. None of it seemed to mean anything important. Even Price's decisions through the game apparently aren't supposed to reflect on him as a person and it's terribly strange, for one example. Why demonize Mr. Tailor and make it seem like he's an axe murderer if we're supposed to sympathize with him, for another? In the end, all the horror elements are nothing more than a coat of paint over a boring story about repossession. None of them end up having an explanation or even a meaning. Don't go through the game trying to make sense of what looks like worldbuilding-- nothing's actually there. 

The ending was crass and unfulfilling. 

It's fine if you just want something to fill a couple hours, but I am glad I bought it on sale.

54261758.review:
Encontré este juego mientras buscaba algo nuevo para jugar de mi biblioteca de Steam sin pensar que me iba a encontrar con una joya. 

Distraint es un juego que cuenta la historia de Price, un tipo que tiene que hacer ''esos'' trabajos que hacen que toda la gente te odie por tratar de sobrevivir todos los días..., tiene que sacar a los dueños de sus casas que están endeudados hasta la puta madre con el banco. Al principio lo disfruta y después se da cuenta de que tipo de persona se esta convirtiendo y por esas decisiones que tiene que tomar aunque no quiere, hacen que lo vuelva cada vez mas loco. 

Tengo que admitir que al principio no me emociono la idea de jugar un juego de terror ''indie'' por así decirlo, me esperaba cualquier cosa, pero realmente me encanto y disfrute todo el tiempo mientras lo jugaba. Tiene sus momentos en que a veces los rompecabezas se vuelven muy densos y tienes que tomarte una pausa [strike] (para no tirar la pc por la ventana) 	[/strike] y buscar una guía para saber como seguir adelante (sobre todo la maldita parte de las pinturas azules y rojas, fuck that).

La música va acorde de lo que va pasando e incluso hace que el ambiente te deje muy tenso y siempre atento a que no saltes de la silla por los sustos.

No diría que hay muchos elementos de terror, si, puede que están los jumpscares ocasionales y la música de ambiente, pero si yo lo pude jugar (que soy una miedosa) seguro que vos que estas leyendo esto para saber si vas a comprar el juego vas a poder jugarlo sin drama.

Los controles son simples y para nada complicados, puede ser que sean incómodos, pero al rato de jugar ya te olvidas de todo.

Los logros son fáciles de conseguir si seguís una guía, de lo contrario a la primera pasada del juego te vas a perder varios. Recomiendo seguir una guía SÓLO para saber como sacar los logros, porque después es fácil seguir la historia.

La historia es genial,  todo empieza medio lento al principio y puede que algunos dejen de jugar y no toquen nunca mas el juego, pero les prometo que la historia cuando va avanzando se va poniendo mejor hasta llegar al final.

Y laaaaa mierda, que final :c, no quiero spoilear, pero me largue a llorar porque [b] la señora Goodwin tuvo su final feliz ♥ [/b] , (Price se puede ir a la mierda, aunque casi se ''arrepiente'' de lo que hace , ponele, siguió haciendo todo de vuelta aunque se sentía mal, fuck you Price).

Comprarlo en descuento, aunque en precio completo vale cada centavo por la historia.

[h1] 9/10 volvería a jugarlo. 	[/h1]
Ahora vamos por el 2!

and probably gets betrayed in whatever follows, i dunno cuz i wasn't able to finish this game.
So far i CAN identify with him, poor soul, wants to play in a higher league, but the describtion of the game that you're playing an oh-so-greedy char is pretty misleading. 
IF the guy would have been greedy, on the behalf of old Grannies and old Grandpas, then yes, i would have LOVED to see him fall. 
As i said even when i am the main char of the game.
 
But when he's just trying to survive, i cannot feel anything more than sorry for the old woman who didn't pay the monthly rent, as others, who own/maintain the house are dependent on the old womans  regularly paid deeds, too. Humblebundle can keep their part two of the game, will save the dollar for my LIDL coffee-vending machine instead.

Distraint is a short experience, but it's packed with all the right goodies. Even with its simplistic gameplay and text-only dialogue, it manages to tell the story of Price in a way that it pulls you in and makes you question his motives and actions. It could have gone deeper into the themes that it touches and has some gameplay elements that are left unexplained - but it succeeds in making you feel for Price and by the end it might also leave you with some food for thought.

Sequel is already out and I'm going to jump on it ASAP!

[u]Slight Cons:[/u]

[u][b]7/10[/b][/u]

Its point and click but instead of mouse you move with keys.

Most of the times this path is where you already been. So typical mission look like this:
- walk some rooms
- at the end of this few rooms you find some item
- you cant know where to use this item as solution is unlogical so you looking for place where to use it by clicking action key
- you return to beggining finding out item destination
- you unlock something on this rooms that will make further progress

Its boring walking and searching like that. Desing choice was apparently made because of lack of content. So you just repeat same rooms 20 times.

50333385.review:
I'm amazed how a game can make simple tasks so unnerving. Like helping some guy find his dog is pretty damn spooky. However, I wasn't scared playing the game, it' s not that type of horror.

The visuals (including the gore), lighting, and sound all work together to create some really creepy scenes. The choice to keep the game in a very small aspect ratio works well. The scenes are eerie, they did a great job with the atmosphere of the game.

However, by the end I was getting a little bored of running around. The final scene is contrived for no reason. Many of the other puzzles make some sense, weird sense, but at least there's some thought behind them. Also one of the puzzles has you running around in a time limit. Well, I can't go for that. It's a pain in the ass to have to map out a very similar looking area AND be reliant on a timer.

Overall, Distraint is good and I enjoyed playing it. The small complaints I have are easy to forget about. The game is only a couple of hours anyway. Knowing all that I do recommend that game. It's unique and looks awesome! I gotta check out Distraint 2.

Checkout my curator for more reviews!
https://store.steampowered.com/curator/26701155-The-Pepp-Selection/

49902370.review:
Sweet game.

I loved the macabre world of Distraint. All of the quests had an easy-to-follow plot that left enough mystery to thoroughly creep me out, despite its mostly minimalist art style. The moving backdrops were captivating, physics were smooth, animations were vivid, the sprites being cutesy bobble-heads never detracted from the creepiness, and the characters were all very unique and recognizable; matching the environments in which they were placed. The last part is important because, when a character showed up outside of the environment in which the player met them, it was immediately apparent that they were not supposed to be there, whether they were an illusion or an apparition, which remains an apt story-telling technique in horror games, but, I particularly admire this artist for making it happen in two-dimensional faux-16-bit. The different scenes of this game were so well-formed as individual, and at times extremely life-like spaces, that I was never confused about the mood each character and space were supposed to induce, every time they appeared on my screen.

This game rocked.

But I never write reviews and I wanted to give this game my wholehearted praise for its very small development team (I'm hesitant to assume it was literally just one dude??? That'd be sweet, and very impressive), also, its ease of access for casual players, and, MOST importantly, its accessibility for disabled players.

I'm going to put at the end of this review, THIS IS A      D I S A B L E D  -  F R I E N D L Y   GAME!!!

THIS PC GAME CAN BE PLAYED WITH ONLY ONE HAND!!!!!!!!!!! IF YOU HAVE ONE HAND, OR TWO REALLY SHITTY HANDS, OR JUST A GOOD FOOT, AND YOU CANT PLAY NEARLY ANY GAMES, then give this game a shot. It's a great mix between puzzle, story-based, and spooky. I'm also going to put this at the end of my review for the second Distraint, which, although it was on sale, I paid quite a bit more money for than the first one, just because I wanted to support this very cool creator.

49457974.review:
Well, truth be told I would prefer a neutral vote, but… this is not a “game” per se. 
First, differently to other games of this kind, there is no choice; no matter what you do the outcome is the same. I try searching alternatives without looking any walkthrough, just to find that… there is nothing you could do. There are no hidden items to solve things in another fashion; there is no way to do things differently.
So, with the anterior said. This is an “experience” you “play” this, roaming around, from one place to another and just put the pieces in the obvious slots. Basically, trying to savor the ride. Almost like a clicker. In a book, or movie that is not a problem, you sit and enjoy. But this is offered like a game… and don’t feel like one. 
I understand the idea of the developer. He tried to tell a story using the tools he knows….but the execution is bad. I’m sorry.
Let’s get technical:  the graphics are nice, the music is a little bit pretentious (trying to drag you into the terror thing…doesn’t work), mechanics… there is “puzzle solving”, but so basic that there is no level of deepness or complexity or even fun in it. Story, yes that’s something you get. Replay value, 0.
I love a good story, and this one is just…basic. So basic that doesn’t compensate for his lackluster execution. But perhaps some people can enjoy the ride. For me it was just a grey experience.

49388170.review:
Distraint is a small indie game made by a single person which deals with a theatrical, deep, dark story with traces of horror. Is it a good game? I will be reviewing the game with a pro/ con style and end with my conclusion.

Pro:
     The story is amazing. It is an emotional roller coaster with traces of horror, sadness, happiness, and other emotions. If your not big on jumpscares and loud noises do stick with it because the pay off of the story is well worth it.

      The music is great. It sets the mood without feeling too forced. It is used to make the horror feel even scarier or the sad moments more sorrowful.

      The dialogue is great. Even if there is not voice acting the words in the text feel grounded to reality. Something a person in that situation would say and act.

      Graphics are super good. It is dark and grim for scary and sad moments and well light for the opposite emotional moments.

Con:
      The game is short. This is a minor nitpick but the game can last you for like 1 to 2 hours.

Conclusion:
       The game is amazing. It is a worth while experience from the starting title screen. I had a blast getting all the achievements and seeing the story. I know a sequal is made and I am super pumped to grab a copy when it goes on sale. The only negative is that the game is short but with how great the story and how many people made the game, the short length is understandable. I recommend this game to anyone interested.

(a lot of my playtime was actually idle time. this game takes about 2h to finish)

If you've played The Cat Lady, that's what this game is like. Only it's a lot shorter (which isn't a bad thing) and the story isn't as strong. I'm on the fence about recommending this one, but if you want a quick horror experience, then this will do the trick! 

[u][b] What I liked [/b][/u]
+ Art style. Pixel art is everywhere these days (and I'm a HUGE sucker for it) but it's really well done here! The lighting is soft and the colors are beautifully muted. 
+ Story. It's short and sweet. It won't knock your socks off, but it's alright. 
+ Music. Unnerving. Jump scares. Good stuff. 

[u][b] What I didn't like [/b][/u]
- Timed section. You are given just enough time, but only just. It was annoying to go through the halls over and over again whenever I failed. I think an extra second or two would have been great.
- Lack of stuff to discover. Whenever you can interact with something, an exclamation point appears, but a lot of times it's just an empty desk. Also, a lot of rooms served no purpose, which was disappointing. I think all but one of the bathrooms could have been left out and the game would be exactly the same.

48883054.review:
The following review does not contain any spoilers of any kind, so read away if you haven't started playing Distraint yet!
This game was developed by a single developer as the credits state, it's a really impressive game, especially for a single developer.
It's kind of a 2D horror game, the thing that I really liked about it was its atmosphere and well-designed levels.
It's also well worth its price, and it took me about 3 to 5 hours to complete which I see is the perfect length for it.
I also prefer the non-deluxe version over the deluxe one.
Let's talk a bit about the story:
You play as a young man, Mr. Price, whose work is to seize the properties of people unwilling,or unable to pay, which then thinks that his job is harsh and inhumane and starts taking guilt for it.
Visual effects are nice, puzzles sometimes become annoying but that's a minor issue for me tbh, I also never experienced any bugs of any kind, there aren't any ways to die, at least that i'm aware of.
If you still have't purchased it, you should really consider doing so.
Definitely Recommend it!

You know that game you think "OK, it's more than a game".

Its simplistic gameplay may alienate some players who would classify it as a walking simulator - an erroneous term created when one does not know or understand the proposition of something. Although there are reasons in the market. Yeah, I understand eventually.

Distraint tells the greedy story of Price and his career; the relentless pursuit of success, no matter how many you have to suffer for it. It is, anyway, heavy.

Nothing different from what we see around there daily. And it's sad the game you play a reality of these, but at the same time a memorable job done by a single person with the help of his wife and a close friend. You will notice the love deposited in the game during the final credits.

Distraint is much more than a simple game hidden in a quiet game with reasonable puzzles (some not so much, very true) and 2D graphics with eventual moments of jump scares - yes, they are a charm apart.

48399540.review:
There's a lot of goodness in DISTRAINT: Deluxe Edition. It's a small tale with a valuable lesson, though flawed in a few story details and overall a bit weepy. For a short 2D adventure, it skilfully conveys a grotesque atmosphere akin to a chamber of horrors.

Beautifully drawn backdrops and a lavish use of tint contrast the literally big headed character models and their twee walking animations. They simply look funny overall and serve to relieve tension in an otherwise grave environment. Especially the background music is incredibly agitating.

The atmosphere creates a feeling for the protagonist, as his inability to defend himself, or do anything other than looking at and picking up items, makes him and the player helpless to interferences. However, there are are no opponents and thus almost no fail states in the game. The puzzles sometimes feel disconnected from their solutions but to counter that there are always enough hints in the vicinity to guess what could be the next step.

The endearing structure and presentation of the storyline draws on theatre devices and is highly reminiscent of A Christmas Carol by Dickens. With that in mind, DISTRAINT: Deluxe Edition is a cute and spooky diversion.

48377454.review:
Distraint: the seizure of someone's property in order to obtain payment of money owed, especially rent. Definition aside, I wasn't entirely sure what to expect with this game. It was another impulse/sale purchase that I was drawn to because of the "psychological horror" tag and unique art style. I have to say, for a cheap/sale game it's definitely worth playing. 

As I said, the art style gives the game a very unique feel. Although unsettling at times, I wouldn't say that the story is particularly chilling. Jump scares are scattered throughout the game without being gratuitous; they fit in with the story and occur at appropriate moments. In fact, towards the end of the game, certain things will tie in with moments experienced by the player early in the game. It's a nice way of bringing all the little story elements together. The jump scare music could be a bit much at times, but it wasn't terrible. I think my only other complaint would be the walking: there was too much walking at times, and the player character (Price) doesn't move very quickly. It was nothing that would put me off the game entirely, but it did prove a bit cumbersome in certain areas.

All things considered, this was a fun purchase. The story ends about as well as you might expect. The achievements aren't particularly difficult to obtain, especially if you're weird like me and try all sorts of random things (like obtaining water for your coffee from a very, very questionable source, ha ha). The game itself is pretty short, taking around an hour to complete. Definitely worth a look if you're into promising indie games/developers. Might end up checking out the sequel, eventually.

48273871.review:
Distraint es un juego que por méritos propios entra de lleno en esa selecta categoría a la que cariñosamente llamo "juegos raros de cojones".

Y vaya si es raro....interesante y diferente, pero raro de cojones.

Estamos ante una aventura gráfica de autor, sencillita de jugar y con unos gráficos mas bien feuchos que se centra sobre todo en crear una buena ambientación y en contar la sórdida historia de Price, el empleado trepa de una empresa de embargos a la propiedad. Una historia de ambición, arrepentimiento y locura que busca poner el dedo en la llaga e incomodar un poco, no demasiado, al jugador.

La puesta en escena es bastante humilde y limitada, al fin y al cabo el juego esta hecho por una sola persona, pero se deja jugar y reviste al juego de una ambientación inquietante y bizarra que le sienta bastante bien.

Los puzzles son sencillos pero entretenidos, pensados para no retrasar demasiado al jugador y que pueda acabarse el juego de un tirón, básicamente en una sola sesión.

Cierto es que te tiene que apetecer jugar a un juego así, raro y diferente, para poder disfrutar plenamente de él. Es un juego muy personal y extraño, que toca temas mas o menos profundos y reflexivos que suelen ser ajenos al mundo de los videojuegos. No llega a la excelencia de un The Cat Lady o un Downfall... pero está en su misma sintonía inquietante y mal sana donde lo grotesco y lo bizarro son un protagonista mas y que tanto recuerdan al Gran Gignol francés y a las películas de David Lynch.

Juego de autor, ciertamente recomendable... pero únicamente para aquellos dispuestos a probar bocados raros y diferentes. Abstenerse los amantes de los juegos de moda y los predecibles que no se atreven a salir nunca de su círculo de confort. 


7/10

47838390.review:
Finished in just 2 hours, Distraint is a very small independent game, the pixel graphics are very neat, with a flawless soundtracks and a rather nice narration.

The story makes us take control of Mr. Price, a bailiff who just got the job, and sees himself decked with a first task to prove himself: to dislodge a certain Mrs. Goodwin. This first mission will mark him during the rest of the adventure, between morbid visions, stressful noises, guilt. We feel pretty involved in the little adventure that Distraint is.

The adventure/horror side of the game is simple to play, simple to understand, it is just a game of easy riddles but not stupid either. The atmosphere is what I enjoyed the most. Glaucous at will, the visuals and sound atmosphere is well worked and they do really project us into the game. The ending was kind of a surprise for me but it was great, with a little morality and a message from the creator of the game.

Distraint is an intriguing game, short but intense and never boring. Totally worth it for less than 3 bucks.

47787189.review:
[h1][b]ANÁLISIS DE "DISTRAINT: DELUXE EDITION"[/b][/h1]

[h1]Historia:[/h1] 

Distraint se trata de un juego indie con una temática real y muy adulta. Encarnamos el papel de Price, el cual tiene que ir visitando a diferentes personas para embargar sus viviendas. Con un trabajo así, es imposible que no surjan momentos dramáticos y que haya remordimientos. Durante la aventura vivimos momentos de tensión, pena, pesadillas y traumas, combinados con momentos de auténtico terror psicológico.

[h1]Jugabilidad:[/h1] 

Las mecánicas son muy simples, el juego se basa en movernos lateralmente, encontrar objetos para solucionar puzzles sencillos y hablar con los personajes secundarios que nos vamos encontrando.

[h1]Sonido:[/h1]

Uno de los mejores apartados del juego sin duda. El sonido ambiental y la música son simplemente geniales, dotando al juego de mucha tensión por momentos y una ambientación genial. No hay voces, el juego solo nos muestra los textos (traducidos perfectamente al español) aunque no se echan demasiado en falta.

[h1]Gráficos:[/h1]

A pesar de sus gráficos 2D y de la primera impresión que nos puede causar su estética caricaturesca, el juego nos hará vivir momentos de terror que incluso nos harán sobresaltarnos en más de una ocasión. La versión Deluxe mejora algunos detalles de la versión original, como la iluminación, efectos visuales, más color, mejores animaciones, etc.

Mi lista de pros y de contras:

[H1]PROS:[/H1]

- Al empezar los controles pueden ser algo confusos

- La temática

- Los diálogos

- Se han mejorado varios detalles en la versión Deluxe con respecto a la original

- El apartado sonoro

- La ambientación

- La música

- La violencia

- Los puzzles

- La estética es muy original

- Tiene momentos muy emotivos

- Nos llevaremos algún que otro susto

- Perfectamente traducido al español

- Se puede encontrar muy barato (a menos de 1€, a veces incluso gratis)

- Tiene logros Steam

[H1]CONTRAS:[/H1]

- Muy corto

- Mecánicas muy simples

- Es bastante sencillo

- Pocos puzzles

- No es rejugable, salvo que te hayas dejado algún logro por el camino (muy fáciles de conseguir)

[H1]Conclusión:[/H1] 

Si te gustan las historias adultas, duras y explícitas, en oferta a menos de 1€ es 100% recomendable a pesar de su corta duración. Grata sorpresa.​

Si mi análisis te ha gustado o te ha servido de ayuda, agradecería que dejaras un voto positivo para que pueda llegar a más gente. ¡Gracias por leerme! No dudéis en dejar vuestros comentarios o dudas, responderé lo antes posible.

47648078.review:
[code]Puedes ver más reseñas como esta en la mentoría [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/34129733/][u]PIXEL 404[/u][/url][/code]

[h1]Esta reseña no contiene spoilers[/h1]

Jesse Makkonen me ganó totalmente con su magnífica obra de arte llamada “Silence of the Sleep”. Menudo juegazo de terror. Si no lo has jugado deberías hacerlo a la primera oportunidad que tengas si te gustan ese tipo de juegos porque te va a encantar, tanto por su jugabilidad tan original, como por su argumento y por las ideas y mensajes tan interesantes que muestra en esa aventura.

Sabiendo esto, poder disfrutar de una nueva aventura suya era, a priori, una muy buena noticia. Ya sabía que el juego era realmente corto, de unas dos horas, pero algunas veces la duración es lo de menos si la experiencia es buena. Lamentablemente, la experiencia no ha sido lo que esperaba ni mucho menos, aunque esto no significa que haya sido mala, sino más bien insuficiente, demasiado plana y con un terror gratuito que no da miedo y que no tiene sentido ni porqué.

El juego nos pone en el papel de un joven llamado Price, el cual trabaja para una empresa de embargos y su cometido es visitar a las personas para informales de que tienen que abandonar sus casas debido a los impagos. De hecho “Distraint” significa “Embargo”, por si no lo sabías. Como puedes ver, no es que se haya comido mucho el tarro con el título, y es un buen indicativo de lo poco que se lo comió luego para hacer el juego.

Empezamos a controlar al joven Price cuando se dispone a encontrar la casa de una ancianita a la que tiene que darle la mala noticia de que debe abandonar su hogar por el retraso en sus pagos. Ese hecho marcará tremendamente al joven Price, pero ¿por qué? Pues es muy buena pregunta, porque el juego simplemente te dice que esto es así y punto. No hay explicación, no hay motivo, no hay una historia oculta… nada de nada. Simplemente es así y ya está.

Esto le resta mucha verosimilitud al personaje y a la historia en sí misma, ya que presenta unos personajes con muy poco fondo argumentativo, y quiere despertar unos sentimientos en el jugador que es imposible que sucedan porque lleva jugando 5 minutos escasos.

Hubiera estado genial que hubiera habido una historia de fondo, pero que va. Bueno, hay una historia, claro, pero no tiene ni pies ni cabeza. 

Hay que tener en cuenta que Price se dedica a esto, desde hace tiempo, y esa reacción de remordimiento es insustancial y poco creíble, porque no va acompañada de un argumento que respalde dichos sentimientos.

Además, ese terror que muestra el juego tal vez sea el más gratuito que haya podido ver en un videojuego. Mientras desarrollamos la aventura, de vez en cuando irán apareciendo escenas dantescas. Cuerpos mutilados, sangre en las paredes, y demás casquería aderezadas con algunos “sustitos” a modo de apariciones repentinas acompañadas de su correspondiente efecto sonoro. ¿Y la razón cuál es? No la hay. Simplemente ves esas cosas porque sí.

Sí, es cierto que al final del juego uno puede encontrarle una razón a eso, muy rebuscada eso sí, pero aun así sigue siendo una utilización muy burda y gratuita del terror, que es utilizado más como una excusa para crear ambiente que como una razón argumentativa que explique el porqué.

En su aspecto jugable, el juego presenta una jugabilidad parecida a lo visto en juegos como Claire o Lone Survivor, pero mucho más simplificado todo.

Iremos visitando diferentes estancias con sus respectivas habitaciones donde encontraremos algunos objetos con los que interactuar y que utilizaremos para resolver los diferentes puzles que nos presenta el juego, los cuales serán muy pocos y además facilísimos.

Gráficamente el juego es raro, bastante raro. Utiliza una paleta de colores apagados y chillones al mismo tiempo, con una especie de bamboleo en la imagen que bien pareciera que se ha roto en mil pedazos la sincronización vertical.

Los personajes son cabezones al extremo, con unas almendras más grandes que sus cuerpos, y el triple de grandes que casi cualquier objeto que haya en pantalla. Por ejemplo, la mollera del personaje es como diez veces más grande que cualquier váter que nos encontremos en el juego. Ahí es nada.

Sin embargo, el aspecto visual es, en cierto modo, interesante. Es raro, en un ambiente raro, y eso resulta interesante de manera inexplicable. Eso sí, es bastante feo, para qué negarlo, pero tienen su “encanto”, por decirlo de alguna manera.

El apartado sonoro, por otra parte, es bastante bueno. Tiene melodías bastante bien realizadas y muy inmersivas, con ese toque de misterio y tensión que le sienta realmente bien al juego.
Dicho todo esto, igual te preguntas el porqué de darle un voto positivo. Bueno, la verdad es que el juego es entretenido, y aun no siendo un juego notable, no merece un suspenso tampoco. Podríamos decir que es de aprobado raspado y nada más. 

Su argumentación es muy floja, su terror es bastante insulso y gratuito, sus puzles demasiado fáciles y la manera de hacer al jugador partícipe del “drama” que plantea es irrisorio, porque no está bien planteado al presentarlo todo atropelladamente y sin darnos tiempo a empatizar con los personajes ni con la historia. 

Sin embargo, es entretenido durante las dos horas que dura y ofrece algo diferente. Su surrealismo es atractivo, aunque carente de explicación, y puede presumir de tener una personalidad propia que en cierto modo es bastante atractiva e interesante. En definitiva, es un producto de bundle satisfactorio, pero poco más.

47472489.review:
I hated [i]Distraint[/i] immediately, when I saw how awful the characters and their animations were. It distracted me a great deal and I was ready to frustratedly play through the rest of it with gritted teeth. As I got further in, the story and presentation grew on me quickly. We play as Price, a man who evicts old people from their beloved homes in the hopes of scoring a partnership with a large company. As Price repossesses the property of different people, horrible nightmare creatures appear intermittently and nobody except us seems to notice. This is [i]very[/i] creepy, and would be even more so if the game wasn’t at all times soaked in a creepy atmosphere that keeps us expecting these things to happen most of the time. The game’s muddy, confused visuals seem to mostly have been for the purpose of reducing the amount of work for the developer. This title could easily have been a memorable experience if the most light-hearted of scenes weren’t presented with the same creeping dread as all the monsters.

What [i]Distraint[/i] does demonstrate is a very good attempt at short fiction. I’ve repeatedly said I don’t think it’s worth using games over any other medium if you’re not going to use interactivity in aid of the story, and that’s exactly the problem with this one. There are a variety of point-and-click puzzles, but they’re always totally bizarre and unrelated to what’s going on. At one point we’re visiting an institutionalised victim of our repossession, and before we’re allowed to actually see her, we have to arbitrarily find a flower in another, locked room. This adds [i]nothing[/i] to the story, it’s just padding to lengthen a very short game. What the developer would have done well to understand is that a short game doesn’t equal a bad one. Indeed, [i]Distraint[/i] would have done better if it was shorter. In fact, [i]Distraint[/i] would have been better as a short story, because none of the unique traits of video games as a medium are utilised as part of its story. The visuals add nothing, the interactivity adds nothing, and ultimately its shortcomings just butcher what could have been a really good little project.

47164473.review:
Price es un joven ejecutivo en una empresa de desahucios en la cual aspira a llegar a ser socio, pero para lograrlo antes tiene que deshalojar a una anciana viuda, un hombre solitario en el bosque y un adulto promedio de la ciudad víctima de las drogas. Y a pesar de que Price sólo se limita a hacer su trabajo que le permitirá llegar a la cima de la ilusión aspiracional, lo cierto es que le será inevitable no involucrarse en cada una de las historias de los personajes, llegando a sentir culpa, vergüenza y horror frente a la burocracia y los intereses económicos, desatando un dilema ético en su conciencia que descubriremos a través de ciertas pesadillas y encuentros en el más allá.

Más que enfocarse en una determinada mecánica o en la profundidad de los diálogos, Distraint basa su concepto jugable en ir hacia adelante o atrás a lo largo de los escenarios en 2D, resolviendo uno que otro puzzle a menudo sencillo, diálogos breves y sencillos pero con una carga emocional y existencial palpables, ya que toda la fuerza del juego se bada en la metáfora y en la narrativa visual. La atmósfera es pesadillesca llena de pasillos aparentemente interminables y de colores oscurecidos y algo deformados en sus contornos. La música por su parte es acorde a las situaciones llegando a sentirse minimalista. Sin problemas de rendimiento. Cuenta con soporte para la resolución de 3440x1440p. 

Jesse Makkonen, el creador del juego, sin duda logra plantar en Distraint un valioso cuestionamiento sobre los valores y aspiraciones de la sociedad actual que ha puesto al mercado por encima de lo humano, el beneficio personal por sobre la empatía, la indiferencia por sobre la conciencia. Lograr el éxito aspiracional a cambio de tu alma. Un declive que parece empeorar y establacerse con cada generación y con las nuevas tecnologías. Si quieres pasar un par de horas conociendo esta dramática historia y de paso cuestionarte un poco sobre las cosas del mundo, entonces el juego es altamente recomendable para ti.

47159098.review:
So i just finished the game (ignore my play time i went through the majority of it while traveling in an area without wifi) and im not very impressed. The graphics were good looking and the game mechanics were functional but not challenging. The main issue is that the story is just kinda... dumb. It didnt feel rewarding to finish and i didnt feel any attachment to the characters, for a story driven game this is kind of a big issue. 

[spoiler] The story revolves around the main character working for a company that reposesses houses and goes on to make that line of work out to be basically the worst thing a human can do. It does so by attempting to emotionally connect you with an old lady that was kind to you when you kick her out. Thats about all that happens with her before the main character is magically fully connected to her emotionally. The way this job is written about is offputting because it does not seem to understand that there is no stopping this line of work, and just because it can be cruel does not mean it is has to be run by horrific people. It makes the managers out to be a true evil and makes no attempt to show the duality that exists with this job in the real world.	[/spoiler]

Overall this game is not worth playing for its lackluster and at times annoyingly out of touch story.
it is also not worth playing for its horror either because aside from a few jump scares and some "creepy" settings it does not really have much to offer.
