47091535.review:
Horror games can be difficult to talk about. After all, what we find scary is very personal and subjective. So, what kind kind of horror game is Distraint? 

This horror story follows a man called Price, a young man with a hard life who's eager to make his name and find success in the world. To do so, he ends up working in the uneviable business of homes, or more specifially home eviction. In his desire to find success, he ends up in the unenviable job of being the man to kick people from their homes when they stop paying. This in turn leads to him felling guilt over kicking a kind elderly woman from her home, which sends him down a path of guilt and regret. Making matters worse is his own existing struggles of being poor and his parents being dead. This ties in with the games horror of guilt, greed, and regret. 

As to how well it handles these things, that's a bit of a different story. Personally, I enjoyed the emotional struggle of Price. He is the underdog that we root for, the guy down on his luck that we want to see succeed. So, when the world and himself  beats him up for wanting a better life, you feel for him. This is made more apparent when even other people, the people he and his company kicks out understand and are ok with what he does. The old lady he kicks out is actually understanding towards what he does. It creates that feeling where you know a man is hurting over his "mistake", when other people understand why he did what he did. I think it makes for stronger, more believable writing.

The other "message" of the game, "Greed is bad" falls flat on its face though. That's because a) It's a very overdone theme that we all know what is will be said b) feels contradicted by the feelings of Price since he regrets his choice of wanting money and success over people and c) is VERY blunt and in your face about it, which almost always makes a message come off poorly.  There's a couple of points in the story where they explicitly state the message they want to send, which reeks of not trusting the intelligence of the audience. 

The gameplay of Distraint is very simple. You move left and right, talk to people, and solve puzzles. You only have 3 inventory slots, and all the puzzles in the game require no more than two. It's all very simple. Areas are short and small and the puzzles are simple and easy to solve, minus one puzzle involving using mushrooms to navigate an area. That's the most complex puzzle in the game, with the other puzzles involving going to a place picking up an item, and using it somewhere else (I did like the dialouge that you get when you use items in places you shouldn't. It's a nice touch.) 

The game is short and simple, so short that you can beat it about 3 hours. Distraint also doesn't have any replay value aside from some secret achievements. So, you have a short game that you only beat once, maybe twice if you feel like it. 

As for stuff like visuals and audio, they're pretty good. Music is pretty minimalistic, but it adds to the ambiance of all the places you visit, and a couple of tracks are pretty good. The spritework and art is really good, with deatiled and dreary environments that add to the atmosphere. Character sprties look a bit odd, with the giant heads, but they're well made and look good as well. 

So, in summation, if you're someone who enjoys horror games (psychological horror especially) or who likes short length games that you play once, then I think you'll enjoy it.

47036654.review:
[h1][quote=][url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/12146432-La-Cruceta-Inquieta/][b]La Cruceta Inquieta[/b][/url], mentor de Steam[/quote][/h1]
Resulta curioso ver cómo un tema tan de actualidad como los desahucios, pese a que en muchos casos son evidentes sus trágicas consecuencias, puede servir como punto de partida para un videojuego de terror. No obstante, conforme avanzamos en la historia, este hecho cobra más sentido al ver que en realidad estamos ante un juego de terror (aun siendo ligero) psicológico basado en la degradación humana y social en cuanto a la búsqueda del éxito como fin que justifica los medios que lo posibilitan. ¿Hasta qué punto la sociedad actual nos exige avanzar a cualquier precio? ¿Es posible el éxito sin hundir en la miseria a terceras personas? Todos estos dilemas morales sirven a "Distraint" como base para desarrollar una pequeña historia que, sin superar sus carencias evidentes como videojuego indie que es, es capaz de atraparnos con su jugabilidad simple pero efectiva y, sobre todo, con su fantástica ambientación lúgubre e inquietante que, por increíble que parezca, logra, si no ya provocar terror dadas sus limitaciones, sí generar cierta sensación desagradable e incómoda. Además, esta edición "Deluxe" (más allá de la versión gratuita para dispositivos móviles) incluye logros para alargar su vida útil y un apartado gráfico mejorado.

Llegados a este punto, sólo resta preguntarse: ¿serás capaz de vender tu humanidad por un puñado de dólares?

Distraint has a great story and atmosphere, but the gameplay is absolutely not my cup of tea. Utterly random "puzzles" that require no logic, just lots of trial and error.  

The concept and the way the story is told warrants a a playthrough, but I'd recommend having a walkthrough with you to navigate the more obscure and frankly tedious parts. 

The game's biggest strength is the emotional resonance it achieves. Distraint is a morality tale told very well.  

I got the game for free, and I totally respect this was a one-man project, and what's here has been done with polish and heart. for those reasons I give it a recommend.

46036166.review:
[b] Lone Survivor this is not. [/b] If this game interests you, go play that instead. You'll have a better time. That game is actually a survival horror game. This is just a corny, preachy storyline with silly puzzles and mediocre scares. 

The storytelling in this game is extremely heavy-handed - essentially amounting to little more than propaganda against debt collectors. Like - we get it - it's sad when people get evicted from their homes. But what are we supposed to do about it? Just dismantle property rights and let people live wherever they want for free? I'm genuinely open to this discussion (while I do not agree at all with this premise), but the game clearly isn't. In this game, there's nothing to discuss. What's bad is bad, and there's no nuance to it at all. The villains are extremely exaggerated. And the game tries to make stupid jokes constantly, which really detracts from the atmosphere.

To top it all off - [spoiler] the game REQUIRES you to help the protagonist commit suicide at the end! [/spoiler] What a middle finger to the audience. I found it disrespectful to people who have been touched by suicide [spoiler] to force you into that scene in order to complete the game. [/spoiler]

So while I did enjoy the artwork and the atmosphere - the fact that it was created by a single person is not lost on me, kudos - this game's storytelling is far too amateurish to recommended. I'm glad I didn't pay for this. I certainly won't be playing the sequel. I adore point-and-click adventure games. I love survival horror games. I should be the target audience for this. But I felt very disappointed throughout.

45930197.review:
Distraint: Deluxe Edition is a 2D puzzle side-scroller made by Jesse Makkonen for the Clickteam Fusion 2.5 engine. It details the story of Mr. Price, a young expropriator trying to finally secure himself a decent living...but at what expense?

If you liked games like The Last Door or Lone Survivor, or are into the styles of horror found in Fran Bow or the Silent Hill franchise and are looking for a bite sized horror experience you can burn through in a single sitting like a movie, Distraint: Deluxe Edition might be game for you. The game has a chillingly surreal and hazy dream-like atmosphere which does a great job at priming the player for some choice scares which, despite not being particularly original most of the time, always stick the landing. The way it handles its relatively standard themes is, if not particularly impressive 100% of the time, mesmerising in its own right, and the simple effective repetition of its elements result in a story that's both pointed and clear, not to mention concise.

Distraint is a squarely two hour experience, and has a few puzzles which seem oddly obtuse, but the short timeframe makes it relatively replayable in a way similar to a movie being rewatchable, and for only five dollars its not too bad of a grab. The imagery and creepy atmosphere is helped by surprisingly well done sound design and presentation which ultimatetly sells the experience. For a foax-retro horror puzzler with no spoken dialogue or survival mechanics at all, the game manages to feel at once masterfully bone-chilling and cripplingly bleak, even with the simple set up and material.

If you're looking for a masterpiece, you won't find it here, but at the worst of times Distraint: Deluxe Edition still proves to be a creepy spine-tingling descent with Lynch-ian nightmare imagery you'd be hard pressed to find in a game without this one's laser focused structure. Grab it while it's on sale if you're particularly greedy, but you might find yourself feeling guilty about that particular vice.

[h1]a little AMAZING indie game[/h1]
I bought this game catched by the amazing atmosphere and graphics (which I absolutely love), and I found myself in front of a gorgeous little indie game with such a powerful message. The game is long about one hour and an half, but for the price is more than okay. [b]Note: I played only the Deluxe Edition[/b]

[h1]PROS & CONS[/h1]
[b]PROS:[/b]
[list]
[*]Great atmosphere
[*]Very good-looking graphics and effects
[*]Amazing sound effects that create that good ol' tension
[*]Little "puzzles" here and there
[*]Entertaining dialogues, the story-telling is very fluent and stays simple, for a not-so-heavy playthrough without losing its message and "deepness"
[*]THE ENDING!!! It is so crude and amazing I don't have any words
[*]The characters, a-m-a-z-i-n-g
[/list]

[b]CONS:[/b]
[list]
[*]In my opinion the story evolves in a "dumb" way [spoiler]-"This is wrong, I'm bad, I should atone, the lady died because of me"-[/spoiler] but it guess this is just a personal thing
[*]Some levels are a little tedious, and made the gameplay a little boring towards the end, even tho I still enjoyed it and finished the game truly involved in it.
[/list]

[h1]FINAL THOUGHTS[/h1]
Do I suggest the game? Absolutely yes. If you are searching a little indie game to pass the afternoon (or better, the evening), that will satisfy you being both relaxing and intense, with a powerful message, this is the right game.
[strike]Also send many hearts to the dev, he deserves it.[/strike]

45887539.review:
DISTRAINT is a 2D adventure game about a man named Price who is working for a company that seizes people’s property. If he wants to earn a coveted partnership with the firm, he must take on some of their most difficult assignments: kicking an elderly woman, a recluse in the woods, and a drug addict out of their homes.

Some of the puzzles are even quite clever and enjoyable to solve. I really liked using a mysterious green substance to shift between dimensions at the druggie’s place. It required a certain amount of skill at timing to weave through the maze of boarded up doors and holes in the walls before the drug’s effects could wear off.

DISTRAINT is a great experience that I definitely recommend. For those with an impressive game backlog that might shy away, it can be knocked out in just an evening, and it gives you plenty to chew on when you’re finished.

45885457.review:
So about, oh I don't know, a million years ago maybe? I picked up this game in a bundle and it's been languishing in my steam library ever since as I failed to get around to playing it. Then my daughter got involved with the sequel and gifted me a copy when it released so obviously I had actually grit my teeth and get around to playing them both.

So... as it turns out it has awesome art style, great sound design and a solid, if occasionally disorienting, story. Some genuinely creepy moments. It's relatively short - my playtime encompasses two playthroughs, an initial one and one to finish up the achievements, but I would still say it's well worth the price even when not discounted. I really don't want to say too much more because it's the sort of game that could be easily spoilered.

That's not to say it's flawless, it certainly has a few moments when it feels like it's slightly uncertain of what it wants to be. If you lose your sense of what you're doing and where you're going you suddenly become aware of how slowly the character moves and there is a relatively brief running puzzle that I didn't really enjoy and it felt like it didn't really fit the tone the rest of the game was hitting. It is also primarily about telling a story so it's not particularly challenging to work out what to do next so if you're in need of mind bending puzzles this probably isn't for you.

Overall though, it feels polished and well put together in a way you often don't see from single person developers, and I probably should have gotten around to playing it sooner. :)

And all things considered, loans are a good thing; they allow people to not wait years for something like a house. And if the paying-your-money-back process seems unappealling, don't take one out.

Also, unless I'm mistaken, relocation for something like a highway is done by the government, not private firms. And I agree, it's screwed up.

45805581.review:
Okay, let’s start off with some pros:
* The graphics are well done.
* The sound work is good.
* The game’s not too long.

Unfortunately, now let’s list some cons:
* Your character, while walking through this (surprisingly large) graphically well done world walks very, very slowly. If you always knew where you’re supposed to be going and what you’re supposed to be doing, that wouldn’t be so bad. Unfortunately, there are several ‘puzzles’ that aren’t obvious, and (if you’re like me, anyway) you might spend a good ten or fifteen minutes just wandering back and forth, trying to find whatever you missed to advance the story. Even if you _do_ know where you're going, several areas require large amounts of backtracking at that same slow slog.
* About the puzzles – too many just didn’t make any sense. (Spoilers minimized) I found the dog – let me tell the owner. Why the heck am I volunteering to find meat? Why do I suddenly need a flower, and how does that make any sense for where to get it? Surely we could have just come back later, when the place was open?
* Why is there a timed running puzzle in this game?! And why do I have to re-do the entire section if I miss it?!
* About the story – the author certainly didn’t feel the need to be subtle. 

I ended up looking up a guide after I missed an object on the second job that you had to backtrack to find and ended up wandering the entire area at our hero’s slow, slow walk speed for what felt like forever. I kept the guide open (and was glad I did so) because of the number of puzzles that are just not obvious (at all) – especially in the retirement home; although the third job and your office weren’t exactly straightforward either.  

The game was decent enough that, having started it, I went through to finish it (helped that the game only took about 1.5 hours), but I don’t think I’d recommend it to others.

45802585.review:
What you have to realize is that this is a wildly stylistic game and it is really easy to start nitpicking about the dumbest things. If you see people going: "0mG tHe GaMePlAy SuXx" it makes all of us roll with our eyes.. right? Distraint is obviously very story driven. Gameplaywise - what you expect is what you get really. There are some minor puzzle elements that can be decently challenging, but overall it is a very story focused game that tries to send a message. There is not much more than walking. 

Now what you can rightfully complain about however is how that story is delivered.

I adore atmospheric experiences in gaming. Now the real masterclass of that is telling a story ONLY through visuals. A lot of artistic choices that seem irrelevant at first sight could play a significant role for the players experience. We learn by exploring, advancing in the game and without anyone saying a word it clicks for you. What the game is trying to tell you becomes a riddle and bit by bit you manage to grasp the full picture. 

Now Distraint.. doesn't have to much of that. It's a hybrid for that matter, given how it still has quite a bit of dialogue but it also becomes blatantly obvious that it's trying to go in that exact atmospheric direction. Dont get me wrong, it has atmosphere! And it manages to sustain that atmosphere well! Hell, I'd even go as far as to say it's a psychological experience. I'll explain what I disliked about it further below.  

Personally I'm not a fan of horror games, and I especially dislike jumpscares. This is tagged as horror, and I realize that I'm not the exact target audience with that, but I wanted to give it a fair try anyways. So take this with a grain of salt. Now tell me, is there really a need to scare me at any given chance if it doesn't pack any real relevance to the story? If anything, the absurd amount of jumpscares really put me off and I quickly became annoyed by them. This didn't take to much away from the distressing feeling, maybe it even added to the stress and general experience you feel while playing - but it definitely annoyed me and ruined my immersion at times. If jumpscares aren't for you this should be a big point to keep in mind when you consider buying, but there is definitely a reasonable amount of thought behind why it tries to scare you so much and really accomplishes that as well, I felt very uncomfortable throughout most of the playthrough but can't say I enjoyed the experience overall, and that is what matters most to me personally.


It pains me to give this a thumbs down because seeing how much effort was put into it and how many ideas took part in all the distressing and generally creative bits of the game it truly shows that someone gave this game a lot of thought. But it is simply not for me. Now the story is actually quite decent, and I really favor the not so happy ending it has as it fits the message of the game very well. Don't let it discourage you in any way though, for the price it is worth at least a try. 

For fans of LIMBO, Inside.

Short review for a pretty short game.

DISTRAINT is a simple game in its gameplay. With just four buttons to use (left, right, interact and inventory) is very immediate. Puzzle are pretty fast and aren't frustrating because objects do interact the way they are meant to.

The story is obviously the point of the game and while its message it's pretty profound, it fails in a few aspects, the first one being the writing, which sometimes falls down a bit. Dialogues could have been better, as often I had the feeling that the character were repeating the same things multiple times, as if they did not want the player to forget something.

The horror side of the game is there, but wasn't really necessary to be honest: the story could've been told without allucinations, an undead elephant and stuff. In fact, I think the narration could've been better if the game had been only a dramatic adventure rather than an horror one.

I found the graphic style the be very neat: it always worked but for the scenes with the undead elephant. I really didn't like those.

The atmosphere, ambient sounds, narrative and mesmerizing pixeled graphics were so emotionally designed that I made it to the end in one go, without any breaks. and boy am I glad I did so.

45756310.review:
Story was not compelling at all. Characters lack depth and I fail to understand the character's motivations throughout the game. [spoiler] Why does Price care about the old lady who can't pay her bills, even to the point of offering to house her in his own shitty home? Why does Price feel guilty about giving eviction notices at all? If he were a policeman, would he feel bad for arresting criminals because it would ruin their lives? His morals don't make any sense. How is doing your job greedy? The player is meant to feel empathy for the old lady, but only because she's an old lady... and her husband recently died I guess? He's not using unethical methods to forcefully evict people, so why the guilt? The 3 big bosses make it sound like he's an enforcer, but all he does is deliver the message and perform some odd jobs so the people aren't too sad about losing their home. The second guy didn't even seem to care he was getting evicted. The third REALLY didn't care it seems. So why is Price all broken up over it? 	[/spoiler] I understand what the game was trying to do, but it did not execute it well. 

The puzzles were not challenging and made little sense logically. You end up wandering around interacting with everything until you find the next step, then you do it again with everything you just interacted with. [spoiler] You distracted the secretary and got the phone to ring? okay. now go to the 3 safes again and now the next one will open with no indication until you get there. Picked up some salt? what do you do with it? dump it in the coffee of course! makes perfect sense. not. grabbed a crowbar from the lady in the cemetary? of course the next step is to use it to prove to the groundskeeper that there's an intruder! instead of beating him over the head. They weren't all like this, but constantly interacting with everything again and again is not my idea of a puzzle. The matches/paper/log made sense at least, and had cues to find and use them. Why didn't a lot of other items? Inconsistent. [/spoiler] 

The long walks with nothing to interact in-between was jarring and broke up the pacing of the game. Normally, when it's used, it's for a critical moment or revelation, but in this game it is constant. Expect to walk through hallways for a large part of the game with nothing to interact with. 

Pacing of the game is slow. Instead of building up suspense or atmosphere, I found myself getting bored. Constant fade ins and fade outs. Long hallways with nothing. Smoke that obfuscates if you're actually moving or if you hit an invisible wall.

If you want horror adventure with puzzles, just play an escape room type game instead.

45750219.review:
Antes de empezar a hablar del juego me gustaría decir que lo he obtenido de forma gratuita, ya que el creador lo regaló hace un par de dias para celebrar el lanzamiento de DISTRAINT 2. Dejando eso claro, voy a empezar:

Este juego es raro de narices. Y no, no estoy hablando del apartado sangriendo o gore del título (que es bastante explícito..). Estoy hablando de la dirección del mismo, parece que el creador no tenía muy claro exactamente hacia que lado quería tirar. ¿Invertimos tiempo en desarrollar personajes como los inquilinos de las casas, la justicia de las leyes.. o hacemos que el viaje del protagonista sea un juego de terror sin nada mas que contar? Mmm, supongo que podemos hacer ambas. Pero como suele decirse, quien mucho abarca, poco aprieta. 

Para empezar, este juego tiene un gran problema de jugabilidad y diseño de niveles. Al principio no es algo de lo que te das cuenta, porque la historia avanza relativamente rápido, pero en cuanto llegas al último inquilino te das cuenta de este problema [spoiler] ¿Usar setas alucinógenas para encontrar un trocito de un cuadro, que te abre una puerta, para poder llamar a tus jefes y contratar a una banda de BLUES...?? Wat.  Quiero decir, se supone que el juego habla del drama del desahucio.. no de dar vueltas hasta que te sale una especie de monstruo a indicarte hacia que lado no tienes que ir. [/spoiler]

También hay elementos del mismo que me sobran totalmente. Quiero decir, no entiendo porque en un juego tan corto donde, literalmente no puedes morir, hay cientos de puntos de guardado. Mas allá de eso, tampoco entiendo porque hay un inventario cuando la mayoria de objetos que tienes los vas a usar casi inmediatamente. Entre otras muchas cosas más.[spoiler] Los famosos cuartos de baño que siempre están, pero el protagonista nunca usa XD [/spoiler]

Me hubiese gustado disfrutar un poco más las zonas donde puedes interactuar con los inquilinos, para poder conocer mejor su historia y como han llegado a esa situación [spoiler] Cuando vas a visitar a la ancianita lo disfrute muchó, aunque de nuevo, sentí que realmente me estuvieron haciendo dar vueltas como un tonto durante 20 minutos. Y la conversación con la anciana es inferior a 3 minutos, ¿realmente compensa? [/spoiler]

Y bueno, dejando eso atrás, artísticamente el juego es muy bueno.  Los escenarios estan muy bien dibujados (a mano) y tienen bastante detalle. Con respecto a la duración, yo lo he terminado en 1:40 horas y si hablamos de su precio, yo creo que es bastante asequible.

PD: Gracias al autor por moverse e incentivar que traduzcan su juego al máximo de idiomas posible, es siempre de agradecer que los autores de los juegos colaboren con los fans para que estos puedan traducir su juego con la mayor facilidad posible.

45750147.review:
Distraint was given away for free on Steam earlier this week to promote the successor Distraint 2. As I'm currently playing through a handful of horror games which have accumulated in my Steam library, the giveaway came at the right time.

Distraint is a short but original indie game about a young man working his way up in his company as a debt collector. He's haunted by pangs of remorse but continues anyway. To do so, simple fetch quests have to be completed.

Finally, a unique setting for a horror game. Distraint's horror is subtle and indirect, a horror that comes to life when putting oneself in the protagonist's shoes. The tone of the story is dark and bizarre with a humorous slant. The soundtrack is selected perfectly and adds to the impression that the developer used very limited resources for maximal effect.

45736861.review:
DISTRAINT: Deluxe Edition is less of a game, than it is an experience. Anyone who's finished, or even attempted to beat a vintage point and click adventure will find its puzzles to be painfully obvious, dull, and require a frustrating amount of backtracking. But, mechanical innovation isn't really what this game's about. Distraint is an interactive story...with very little interaction.

But,maybe that can be forgiven. How is the story? Well, that's a mighty subjective question. Distraint's narrative is a blood drenched cautionary tale of [spoiler] how working in debt collection leads to a self-destructive spiral of madness and guilt that invariably ends in suicide. [/spoiler] In my opinion, it handles its subject matter with about the nuance and subtlety with which Reefer Madness (Louis Gasnier, 1936) portrays stoners. There were multiple times I had to pause this "Psychological Horror" just finish laughing at its latest insane reveal. [spoiler] This includes a recurring jumpscare of a LITERAL elephant in the room, that comes barreling through walls like the Kool-Aid Man. But, don't worry. If you missed the symbolism, a character will eventually straight-up tell you the Elephant is actually your guilt. [/spoiler] So, no. Neither the story no the symbolism did anything for me. I also found the writing to be little more than an embarrassing litany of cliches. 

However, there is one area in which Distraint undeniably exceeds: style. And, WOW does it ever succeed. Credit where credit is due: this game looks amazing. The pixelated film grain, joyless color scheme and downright incredible lighting make keep the game visually engrossing. The audio isn't lacking either. Every bit of music is pitch perfect for the emotional tone each scene *tries* to evoke. Stylistically, there is nothing else like Distraint. Its artistic style succeeds where virtually all of its contemporaries fail: creating an ambiance of genuine dread. 

So, if you want a few hours of depressing as hell eye-candy, this is WELL worth your time. However if you're looking for a game that delivers real psychological horror, I'd advise you keep looking. Distraint isn't without its charms, but there's just not enough present to make it a solid recommendation.

45710236.review:
This was probably one of the weirdest and heart-wrenching games I've come across to date. For me, this was a very appealing experience for a kind of a side-scroller game I'm not too fond of. 

A more simple approach in graphics and the story, including the few puzzles included in the game mechanic itself and as an outside elemen, the athmosphere in the world you were put in kept you in a relative suspense throughout and the feelings progressed quickly from horror to sadness to guilt towards the end and the ending itself was well executed. 

There were good horror elements and I was extremely happy to see there were no jumpscares to speak of. A word of warning, though; some of the "surprises" or "jumpscares" were somewhat disturbing in nature, but they were kept suble enough not to steer you away from the game.

As with any game, there were some problems. One of them was the use of up and down keys that you could define but were non-existent in the game (or at least I didn't find any use for them). Also finding certain things were a bit difficult although I blame myself more as I practically walked near it multiple times without realising what it was. There were also a few issues with the dialog progression, such as the main character finding a certain thing and going to the secondary character only to say he will talk to him once this certain thing was found. These small issues really don't matter as they're not game breaking glitches but you may find them somewhat frustrating.

One drawback is that the game itself has very little revisiting value once it is played through, but don't take my word for it as I only speak for myself. 

If you are into games that have horror elements in them, like to solve some puzzles (they're not that hard, if you focus on them) and can withstand the probable crushing feelings that this game produce at the end, I recommend playing it.

I'll give this game a solid 7/10.

45701558.review:
I enjoyed this game ( I played the Deluxe edition, which I claimed for free during a promotion ). It was fairly short, but it had well-balanced puzzles and good sound design. The art is good and the pacing of the story is alright. Gameplay is secondary to atmosphere and story, but not in an inferior sense! The story is the most important part of this game, and the gameplay is centered around this. The puzzles are simple and there's always dialogue or quirky text to tide you over in moments of boredom with the mechanics. 
My only gripe would be the layout. In a particular level you need to run through specific rooms and doors on a timer to solve puzzles, but due to the game being 2D you have no idea which doors connect to which rooms and which hallways. The puzzles remain simple enough that it isn't too overly frustrating to blindly force your way through, but it is not very fun to get stuck on a timer and confusing layout when you KNOW the solution to the puzzle. 

The story itself is a little mediocre in my opinion. More so in execution than in concept. I don't think the story was particularly suited to horror, and thus this game is not very spooky at all. The atmosphere is great, but after long stretches of time without actual depth to the scares and horrors you encounter, you realise that there is nothing that can hurt you in this game and that any actual death is scripted and intended. 

(spoilers for the plot below )

Throughout the entire game our protagonist Mr Price is battling his guilt over taking away people's homes and properties. This guilt is what is driving him crazy and making him see things that aren't there - including his long dead parents, a zombified animal that chases him, and an old lady he evicted. ( This old lady haunts him the most, despite him meeting her only once and looking at about 4 of her items ) 
As the story goes on however, he never seems inclined to stop doing the things that are making him feel guilty. Worse yet, a lot of the guilt that he feels is misplaced; he isn't responsible for the death of an elderly lady, he isn't capable of cancelling huge projects like a highway for a forest-dwelling hermit, and if he didn't evict the man that couldn't pay his rent his bosses would simply fire him and hire someone else to do it! 

By the end of the game, our protagonist takes a position of CEO, a position in which he SHOULD be able to take responsibility and treat people kinder than the others, but instead he lets the guilt for his previous actions consume him. He gets fired, loses his home, gains debt, and ends up getting evicted by someone who is doing the job he once did. 
The ending of the game shows that this game is part of a never-ending cycle of greed vs guilt, and it is an interesting thing to think about. Sadly, the game that comes before this ending doesn't do a very good job of showing the nuances in this cycle. Mr Price felt guilty over things he had no control over, and remorselessly continued doing the things that he COULD control, making him hard to relate to 'till the very end. 


(Spoilers End) 

Overall I recommend this game. It's price tag is very reasonable for the content and game-length provided, and despite its flaws it is an enjoyable and interesting experience. I frankly wish that it had focused a little more on improving the scope of its horror - or that it had put more attention towards the story and the motivations of our main character.

45694076.review:
Wow. A surprisingly good experience. I'm just gonna write my quick thoughts upon finishing it while it's still fresh in my mind. SPOILERS.

The whole concept of greed was done very well and reinforced throughout. I especially liked a scene towards the end where you keep drinking the water, yet you never satisfy your thurst even when you feel like you can take no more. The shift from being about to quit to staying with the company upon seeing the sign with his name on it is a pretty realistic scenario which was done extremely well as well. On a side note bonus points for his name being Price to really reinforce that materialism. I also found it interesting how the struggle between what's legal and what's ethical is shown. In all honesty you can have solid arguments for either side. "If you had managed your money better you wouldn't be in this situation so you have no one to blame but yourself" vs "There is too much bueraucracy intentionally made to confuse you so it's not fair", although in all honesty I am with the legal side slightly more. I also liked how the bloody corpse you see in certain moments turns out to be you in the future when you blow your brains out. Nice touch.

There were a couple of things I didn't like. Firstly, the ending was good which shows the never ending cycle of greed and ambition, but I'm not a fan of the implied suicide of the protagonist. The foreshadowing of the image was great and all, but don't make me write a fucking suicide note and pull the trigger. A minor nitpick is that I expected to be chased by the gravekeeper since his design was probably the most disturbing for me, but that didn't happen sooo... oh well. I also didn't buy the whole relationship with the granny. If anything she had a better life in the nursing home with other elders and a pet rabbit by her side when compared to living alone and rotting away. 

Finally for those who want to know I got stuck twice (which is a record for me since I suck at these sort of games). Firstly, I couldn't find the hanger so I was going crazy trying to get this old piece of shit to stop blocking the door. Secondly, I couldn't find the cash to make the phone call which turned out to be in a trash can that was in a room I never went in to begin with. A brilliant little game that's genuinely creepy and moving in equal measure. The sound and music are both excellent and the puzzle/progression elements of the game are clever and simplistic enough to appeal to just about anyone, especially casual gamers. The art style is also wonderful and perfectly suits the overall tone of the game which I like to think of as 'Cute Dread'.

This game is essentially a tale of greed and redemption that's kind of like a cross between Uncanny Valley and Drag Me To Hell, sans the Lamia, Hell and android bits, and with a nice little twist at the end.

Anyone looking for a quick little psychological horror fix should give this a go....and it's currently free for a limited time so there's no excuse not to play it.

45657402.review:
Horror, blood, elephant, 2D pixel's graphic and a cup of cofee. Money rule the world and feelings are buried under the ground. But, only with money, you will be never fully happy and you will never give a true sense to your life....

This short story is more than a game. This is actually a full morale lesson for everyone that will play this game in the correct way.
Don't buy this game if you want just to have fun or relax, buy this game because you really want it and you are really intrested in the hidden messages inside of it; because with this game you will learn again to:

- Keep a promise
- Think twice about your decisions
- Don't be greedy
- Money don't give you happiness and completeness in this world

The game is a 2D based "adventure" where you play the role of a worker for a expropriations agency. 
The gameplay itself is pretty much linear with several puzzles in all the situations. There will be only one way to play but I really suggest to play this game twice not only for the hidden achivements but to understand better the story itself.
The choice of the music is really sweet and helps a lot to transmit feelings to the player. It will even give you the chills during the "horror" parts.
Graphically don't expect a lot of "sweet effects" but the choice of the colors and the "noir" style gives a quite good look to the narration.

You can play this game both with keyboard or a 360 XboX controller.

In the end: for being a game made from a single person with the help of his wife this is a quite amazing experience. Again, as I said in the beginning, do not buy this game if you are simply looking for fun or you will never fully enjoy this game.

Overall:
Graphic: 7/10
Sounds: 8/10
Longevity: 5/10
Morale: 9/10

45537108.review:
Distraint:  Deluxe Edition: Sppppooooky business decisions

The world can often be a harsh place where no matter how good a person you are or can be, life can just sometimes screw you over.  Distraint tries to portray this from the point of view of an intern at some sort of property firm who has to force people to force people to leave their homes due for a verity of reasons and factors.  Well...just keep reading and find out.  

Distraint: Deluxe Edition follows a young man called Price as he is forced to (as part of his job) remove an old fail woman named Mrs Goodwin from her home after she cannot pay the bills.  This sends Price into a deep existential crisis about his ambitions and the consequences of his actions the particular line of work.  Before I get into my criticisms of the plot I would like to stress that the atmosphere is very good and does it produce some good scares.  The plot has a very Silent Hill feeling to it with taking the emotions a person is experiencing and giving it a physical form; twisting it into some truly distressing scenes and concepts.  The smaller quieter moments are well paced and carry legitimate tragedy. 

Right, now that we have gotten that out of the way....

I will always try to praise a game for attempting to fulfil or ape a certain game series like Silent Hill (We will never get another one short of a company imploding or the IP being sold off). The trouble with this game is a lack of nuance in the writing and a lack of subtly in the horror.   The three business men that Price has to win over in order to join the firm are so cartoonish and over the top they would not look out of place in a Captain Planet episode.  I understand that the game is trying to make its message clear to the audience but it goes so overboard that it stops being scary and ends up becoming silly.  Mrs Goodwin herself is meant to be the sweet innocent that was destroyed by a cruel and uncaring system: I know this because the game was so terrified that I missed her purpose as a construct that it keeps reminding me of it in long overdrawn set pieces that get tedious.  But to my mind the worst offender of this lack of subtly comes when a pair of hallucinations just flat out explain what they are meant represent; I rolled my eyes because not only of the bad writing but just how little faith the developer had in his audience to think for themselves.  The story itself when you look at it is not particularly scary.  There is potential due to the relevant themes but the execution is off.  I walk through the woods looking for a missing dog and I am assaulted by sound shrieks and spooky visuals popping in and out like the weak source jump scares they technically are.  It does not feel like a horror story but more a tragic drama that has horror haphazardly slapped on it.  I cannot help but wonder if the game had improved if it had lost the horror angle (or reduced it) and made it a depressing tale of a man trying to hold onto his Humanity in the face of promised wealth.  When the game is quiet and sombre it works better as a story, the ending itself (not going to spoil) is a great example of this. 

The gameplay is mostly simple 2d puzzle solving.  You move either left or right examining everything for items which would help you process.  Think of it as classic point and click with the E key and space bar replaying the clicking and the puzzles being less convoluted.  As long as you use your head you should be fine as the items you find will work with what you expect the item to work.  A pair of matches, a pile of twigs and a fireplace (pretty easy to put together considering you need to light the fireplace), the rest of the game is spend walking from one place to another sometimes seeing something spooky and scary.  To be honest, this is fine. It works well.  It is basic but well done puzzle solving that rides real world logic. It is perfectly good.

The game runs very well, no flaws what so ever. 

Distraint should be a great game, there is good promise for something really interesting but it is bogged down by rather rubbish writing. Try Lone Survivor instead.

45352874.review:
[h1]On sale or bundled, it's worth it.[/h1]
While I did win this game in a giveaway, I can't say I would have purchased it otherwise. The gameplay style wasn't very comfortable to me but I played it from start to finish before writing this review. I wish that Steam offered an in-between option for recommendation. I would only recommend this game to others, depending on their gaming tastes. For someone like me, I would not recommend it. While I enjoy indie games and horror games, this one lacked in the story and plot values that many indie games are known for. 

[h1] The Good [/h1]
[list]

[*] Published and Developed by a single creator (Jesse Makkonen)

[*] Has genuinely scary/wtf moments

[*] Has easy to complete achievements (easy to 100%)

[*] It isn't bad for a casual 4+ hr completion

[/list]

[h1] The Bad [/h1]
[list]

[*] Short. $5 price tag for around 4+ hours of gameplay. 

[*] A very strange plot that, even after completing, is very hard to understand. I have no idea what was going on or why it was going on. I wasn't sure if the main character was going insane, was possessed or if he was being haunted 

[*] Tedious problem-solving that typically required backtracking or going around in circles when you didn't know where to find what you were looking for. [spoiler] Ex. The 2nd 'mission' (or whatever you would like to call it) requires a piece of paper to light a fire, when the firelogs are damp. That piece of paper can only be gathered after a certain point, even if you looked in the trash can beforehand. I spent probably 5-10 mins looking for something and I didn't know what. [/spoiler]

[/list]

[b]TL;DR: If you're wanting this game, wait for it to be on sale or in a bundle. [/b]

Más que un juego de mecánicas y aventura, Distraint se enfoca en el desarrollo del personaje y en el mensaje que el autor quiere transmitir. 
La trama utiliza la idea de alguien que ha corrompido en totalidad su alma, idea antes planteada por Edgar Allan Poe en William Wilson, Oscar Wilde en El retrato de Dorian Gray y William Shakespeare en Hamlet, cada uno haciendo que el protagonista tome uno de los 3 caminos disponibles (no os diré cuál camino toma este juego).
La música y escenarios son formidables los cuales generan una gran inmersión haciendo que el juego se convierta en una gran experiencia y resalte el mensaje principal, además de ser notoria la dedicación y el amor puesto por el desarrollador.

44715453.review:
Great little indie game. 

Distraint is a story first and formost. There are puzzles, but most aren't especially challenging, and the narrative is definitely the most important part. The story is also nicely paced and talks about a kind of "evil" that I don't see in many other games. Gameplay is not especially exciting. It is just your normal, "find the item, do something with the item" system. 

As far as aesthetics go, the sound is pretty decent, and I like the graphics. The visuals are simultaneously a little derpy, and a little offputting. 

Distraint is almost like a movie, in that the story is the most important, and it'll take you about 2 hours to complete. I would recommend setting aside an evening and playing through in one sitting. 

All in all, 7.5/10. Would definitely pick it up while on sale, or even full price. It's $5

Distraint is a psychological horror (it’s not scary though) with some surreal elements about a man named Price who just started working for a company where his job is to seize peoples properties. Price doesn’t enjoy the job for obvious reasons and he starts to hallucinate and have nightmares as his mental state deteriorates due to not being able to deal with the moral issues regarding what he does for a living.

It's a pretty short game (took me 2 hours) but the story is interesting, gameplay is pretty simple and straightforward, puzzles aren't difficult and the art and sound are really good. The ending of the game was also a lot more interesting than I thought it'll be.

I would definitely recommend this little gem.

44358386.review:
At first glance, this game might look like another boring 2D pixel game. But once you start the game and get a sense for the story, you are hooked. 
  The main positive about this game is obviously the story. I was captivated after just the first half an hour of gametime, and it just kept getting better. The game plays with your emotions and teaches you life lessons that could change the way you perceive the world. Yes, this game has had a huge impact on me, and I think it can have the same effect on others.
  The artstyle of this game is beautiful to say the least, and sometimes scary even. The character experinces many moral dilemmas, and some of the representations of those struggles come to life in a spectacular way. An example would be his fears manifesting into a scary animal and other hallucinations which leave you with a nasty case of the goosebumps.
  The only downsides I can think of is that the gameplay itself can potentioally be a bit repetetive, and the game is quite short. But sometimes, short can be good too. And this time it might help the game overall.

9.8/10

44282175.review:
The game is ok, but not really worth playing. The game appears to be a horror game, but the important part of a horror game is the threat, which there is none. You realise this after about 1/2 hour in. 

The game is very story focused. The sory is about [spoiler]the mental degrade of[/spoiler] the guy you play as because of [spoiler]the guilt he feels[/spoiler]. It just so happens that he halucinates spooky things. The story could have been just the same (and maybe better for the ending) without the "horror" aspects.

The gamplay is ok. Mostly a point and click style of gameplay. Walk around, pick up things, use things on thing. Never really felt like a "use everything on anything because the solutions are convoluded," but progress can be blocked if you missed 1 interactable.

Overall, its ok. If this still sounds interesting, maybe give it a shot.

Got this game for free, and must admit it felt like a steal. It's one of those one-man short games that surprises you on how well it's made. The soundtrack makes you feel uneasy and paranoid, the jumpscares (I must admit I hate them in general though) didn't feel so invasive or out of place, they actually serve purpose in the plot. The pixel art graphics are beautiful, and for it's length I must admit it's worth the price.

Definetely looking forward to buy the sequel.

Overall score 8/10

43820008.review: This is a very interesting pixel horror game. I throughly enjoyed Distraint. I got a couple jumpscares from it, but for the most part, I really enjoyed its sad story. I was not expecting a great many of the plot twists to occur, especially the ending. It's not one of those super short stories either. Granted, you could complete it in less than a day, but I took my time and split it into two nights over the course of a few hours.
